They were aware last night that a number of Aboriginal demonstrators remained on the firing range. Their locations are generally known, or were known last night. It has been proposed that this morning-and I understand this is now happening-a full scale sweep of the area take place to identify and remove from the Commonwealth firing range the people concerned. I am assured by the office of the Minister for Defence that there is no question whatever of any bombing or other firing activity taking place on the range unless they are, I was told, 150 per cent certain that there is no person exposed to danger or on the range environs. It is an understandable concern that has been expressed. We acknowledge that concern. The matter had already been brought very much to the attention of the Government and Defence authorities.

The action that has been taken is as I have described it. Accordingly, I believe there is no need for further concern on the part of the Democrats or anybody else, although, of course, the policy issues are acknowledged by us to be still ones of public debate. That is a debate for another occasion. The substance of the motion this morning, as I understand it, was the concern about immediate risk to life and the immediate prospect of physical injury. There is no concern on that account, whatever the continuing concerns on the larger public policy issue might be. I hope that short statement will set the issue at rest at least for the moment.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN TELECOMMUNICATIONS CORPORATION BILL 1989AUSTRALIAN POSTAL CORPORATION BILL 1989TELECOMMUNICATIONS AND POSTAL SERVICES (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1989TELECOMMUNICATIONS BILL 1989TELECOMMUNICATIONS (APPLICATION FEES) BILL 1989

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) whether he is approaching this matter on the basis that the board of Australia Post would be in a position to direct that persons other than postal employees be engaged on a short term contract basis if the need arose.

—The answer to the honourable senator's question is that Australia Post regularly contracts people and has contracted people in appropriate circumstances over time. It is in my mind that about 9,000 contracts have been let, or 9,000 people have been engaged. But the central point of what the Government is saying on this matter is that if there is an industrial dispute-to use the example the honourable senator used to justify the amendment he proposed-then the proper authority to deal with it is the employer, and the employer is Australia Post, represented by its board. The board should be accountable for the management of its employees. If the employees are in dispute, the board should be accountable and should do all things right and proper within its ambit to bring that dispute to an early close. Regarding the question specifically asked by the honourable senator, it is within the power of the board to make contracts as it sees fit.
—Does that mean that, in the event of prolonged disruption, the Board would be able to contract out all of the services involved in the delivery of mail for the period of the disruption?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a speculative question. It invites me to speculate about a certain set of circumstances which have not occurred and which arguably may not occur. It would be foolish and somewhat naive of me to joint with Senator Alston in his speculation. Let me say that the board, in the face of an industrial dispute, ought to do all things right and proper to bring that dispute to a rapid conclusion. I argue this point frequently. I recognise that the honourable senator has an ideological blinker to it and is thus unable to receive the message. The message is simply that if one has an industrial dispute one must deal with the problem that causes the dispute, not layer on top of that problem other problems which would exacerbate and broaden the dispute.

SPEECH.PARA: It may be that the theatre of industrial relations appeals to the Opposition as a theatre in which it can perform as a disciplinarian. That does not resolve the core issue. If we ever take our eyes off the core issue and how we should resolve it, we will be in deep trouble. Those are my observations. The board will be responsible and the board will be accountable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it from the Minister's remarks that he does not understand what is involved in the reserve power that might exist in the Constitution and in other situations where, as a last resort, a board is able to take decisions which needed to be taken in a period of crisis. Putting that to one side, I ask the Minister what response he expects Australia Post to take to its own union members when the Chairman of the Prices Surveillance Authority has disclosed that Australia Post's own statistics have shown that one in four letters arrive late in Victoria and that performance results are so poor that industrial relations have caused Australia's recent poor showing in Victoria, and has recommended improved internal consultation and greater use of the Industrial Relations Commission to head off damaging disputes.

SPEECH.PARA: Is is not the fact that these sorts of placebo conciliation and consensus approaches have abjectly failed and that what is needed by any party to negotiations is a good hand? It is no use not even having a pair of twos and the other side knowing it because one will get taken to the cleaners every time. If one has the ultimate essential services power, one does not have to use it but it becomes a fairly useful tactical negotiating weapon. Why should a government not have that power as a last resort? It may never intend that it be used. But at the end of the day, unless the Government has some ability to impose its will, unless it has some cards to play that will bring recalcitrant unions to heel, it will have to give in to the demands of those unionists-as the Minister is really conceding-no matter how unreasonable those demands might be. The Minister is an experienced industrial relations negotiator. Why does he not want to strengthen his own hand?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a rhetorical question. I do not know that it really calls for an answer.
—Yes, please. I would like to have an answer.
—Senator Newman might like an answer but I might not give one.
—That is another matter.

—It is indeed another matter. I will not get involved in a debate which requires me to respond to matters of rhetoric. We can have all sorts of flights of rhetoric. Indeed, we can wallpaper this chamber in rhetoric. But I am a practical person. I like to deal with real things and get real results and achieve some output. What would be useful would be to actually pass this Bill as soon as possible so that we can reform Australia Post and make it more efficient and more relevant to the needs of the Australian community.

SPEECH.PARA: There were a number of points that Senator Alston made to which I can respond. The first was a gratuitous observation about the state of law and my actual knowledge of it. I do not propose to engage in a debate with Senator Alston about that because it was a fairly gratuitous observation on his part. I thank him for the observation but I already knew about it.

The second point was a series of premises which were mixed up with some marginal facts to try to make a case in the form of a set of questions. Once again Senator Alston seemed to ignore the fundamental principle, which ought to be a fundamental principle of industrial relations: when politicians get involved in industrial relations the possibility of settling disputes goes out the window because the parties then have some sort of interest in parading their case on the political stage. If one has an industrial dispute, it ought to follow that one isolates what the issue is and that the parties who are involved-in this case it is the board of Australia Post; and presumably whichever fictional unions might, for the sake of this exercise, be involved-should be isolated. The issue should be isolated.

Senator Alston then went on about conciliation and all this consensus stuff; they were his words. I do not know what he means by that. Senator Alston is a lawyer and he knows as well as I that we have a Conciliation and Arbitration Act which requires compulsory arbitration. Therefore, the only option is not the one Senator Alston proposed in his question about conciliation. It is an arbitral proceeding in which, after evidence and argument, a decision is made and imposed. Senator Alston knows that but he chose to ignore it.

Let me now come to the final question: `Why don't I want the hand of the player involved in this to be strengthened?'. That question presumes that the hand of the player is not strengthened. We have a confusion here about who is the player. Senator Alston wants the Minister to be a player. He wants a government to be involved in industrial disputes. We want the Board of Australia Post, which is accountable, to be the player. We want the Board to manage its industrial relations and take responsibility for its outcomes. That is the appropriate way to go. Otherwise we will have the level of industrial disputation in this country that we had in the Fraser years. No one wants that situation to return. In terms of the perceptions of ordinary Australians, let me say that the last poll I saw showed that an overwhelming majority of Australians believed that we were much better at resolving industrial relations problems than the Opposition was when in government. That is a perception borne out by what the statistics show as well. While Senator Alston has an ideological position-I acknowledge that; he is bound to put it; he has done so; he has done his job on behalf of his Party-let us get on with the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Cook departs, I will address this question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans). Senator Cook has been saying that the Government should not be a player in industrial relations; we are talking about a poker game and the Government should be the banker. Let us put the employer at the table and see what cards it has. Why should not the board of Australia Post be given explicit essential services powers so that it can go outside its own work force if there is a need when a protracted dispute arises and it seems incapable of early settlement? That solution has been used in the United Kingdom on occasions, certainly in the last century, and in this country in this century, and is an obviously sensible fall back position to be used as a last report. Why should not the Board of Australia Post be given those sorts of powers?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is difficult to pick up the threads of a debate when I have just come into the chamber, but this is not an issue that is squarely given rise to by the terms of either the substantive clause before us or the amendment. No doubt the debate has taken a fascinating course over the last half hour or so. I will take on notice the matter that Senator Alston has raised and I will ensure that the Department and Australia Post have a look at it. It probably does raise some interesting public policy questions. We can have a look at it in the longer course, but this is not the time to be doing it right now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make sure that throughout the rest of what looks like being a protracted debate on a large number of amendments on this package of Bills that Senator Alston does not jump up again and talk about inadequate responses from the Australian Democrats simply because, as I have said earlier, we want to see the passage of this legislation. I will make it clear, in accordance with the discussion that has already taken place on this amendment, that the amendment is within the context of what we see as the direction of the Opposition in making these decisions. Clearly this amendment, with its industrial relations implications, is a very good example. I will clarify that context by using Senator Alston's own words from a speech which he made to the Royal Australian Institute of Public Administration in October last year. At the end of his very long paper he concluded:

SPEECH.PARA: In essence, therefore, my case is:
(1) Australia Post and Telecom are very powerful and economic institutions which do not presently operate in the public interest.

On that point alone, I certainly draw Senator Alston's and his Party's attention to the research which is currently being undertaken by Telecom which indicates that while the public has some views about matters that might be improved, the public certainly sees the importance of the community service role of at least Telecom. I have every confidence that in spite of a feeling that every institution can be improved-this one no less-the public does understand the value and importance of both those institutions, as do the Australian Democrats. That is why in the whole business of government business enterprises we do not want to see the deregulation approach that the Government is taking so far down the track that these institutions will be utterly vulnerable, whether it is by stirring up industrial relations disputes, or whatever mechanism, many of which underlie the amendments which Senator Alston is introducing and dragging us through one by one. That is a very firm basis for our stance. On the same occasion at the Institute of Public Administration, Senator Alston made the following point:
The Federal Government has a valid political obligation to ensure that genuine community service obligations are met, preferably at public expense.

That is a point which I made a little earlier in the discussion on this amendment. Senator Alston's view, as the Opposition front bench spokesperson on this matter, is that we should not operate community service obligations by cross subsidy, but that they should be costed. That point has been clearly made in the same paper and on many other occasions by Senator Alston. They should be up front budgetary items. So that is an extraordinary double standard. Cross-subsidisation is a common procedure within that form of business which Senator Alston and his Party utterly agree with-the great free enterprise system-and yet he wants to deny it to government business enterprises which do have significant community service obligations.

I will reiterate some of the remarks which I made yesterday: indeed, to undermine these enterprises, in a sense, is to bring down their value and to make them more vulnerable to future political pressures towards privatisation. This is something which the Democrats do not support, and we will not support amendments which move in that direction. We are disturbed by a lack of real distinction between what governments should and should not pay for. Senator Alston is saying that the public should pay directly for the community service obligations of government business enterprises. We have seen this Government cough up big money for some of those wonderful private enterprise sector organisations which are supported by the Opposition. Hundreds of millions of dollars have been spent during this Government's term of office to shore up the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, the banks and the oil companies. In the case of government business enterprises, we believe that we do need to preserve a range of their monopolies in the community's interest.

We will continue to support those aspects of legislation where we believe that this is happening so that they can cross subsidise and community services can be provided as community services and not as welfare services which, as social security spokesperson for this Party, I have seen constantly turned into political footballs not just on a yearly budgetary basis but on a six monthly budgetary basis with only the squeakiest wheel getting the oil. Madam Temporary Chairman, certainly you would understand that in those situations it is very hard for small groups of people, in particular isolated people, to be squeaky wheels. We can just imagine what would happen to the availability of services to people in remote areas, people with disability and people living in poverty. Clearly if the enterprises can conduct their operations and fulfil their community service obligations from within, so much the better. They do not then become political footballs on a twice yearly basis.

We reject this amendment and in almost full measure the large bulk of the amendments that Senator Alston is moving. I really do not want to be accused of not giving a sufficient response simply because I do not take up as much of the airwaves as Senator Alston. I am not looking for a more senior front bench position in a prospective future government.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Alston's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
TELECOMMUNICATIONS AND POSTAL SERVICES (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1989
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Pages 13 and 14, clause 15, proposed section 76, line 37 (page 13) to line 2 (page 14), leave out the proposed section.

The amendment is that proposed new section 76 be deleted. We have run through this argument several times, so I will not go over the same ground. I simply ask why the Overseas Telecommunications Commission (OTC), whilst it retains monopoly status, should be immune from suit. For all the reasons that I advanced yesterday, it seems extraordinary that a very profitable operation should not be able to bear the costs which might be incurred by its customers as a result of the negligence of OTC. Whilst Senator Evans can hypothesise about what will happen if a multinational suffers multimillion dollar losses, one could say, I think with greater validity, that it is much more likely that it will be a multitude of smaller customers of OTC who will suffer. In terms of equity and justice, I would have thought that their interests should prevail. There is no good reason why OTC should retain its immunity from suit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to repeat, for the record, the kinds of considerations which lead the Government to continue to seek immunity for all loss or damages relating to the transmission, delivery or reception of a telecommunication in the legislation. The provision is limited to the areas where OTC provides a reserve service and does not extend to any service which OTC provides in competition. That needs to be understood as a threshold. The Government has decided that OTC should continue to have some immunity from actions in relation to reserve services because to do otherwise could place OTC in a really difficult position. OTC does not have control end to end over communications to and from Australia which pass over the networks of other countries. The idea of immunity in international carriage is not novel. Article 21 of the International Telecommunications Convention of Nairobi in 1981, to which Australia is a party, provides, in terms:

SPEECH.PARA: Members accept no responsibility towards users of the international telecommunication services particularly as regards claims for damages.

In this international environment, unless OTC is granted immunity it could be left to bear the full brunt of actions which for practical purposes, whatever the legal situation might be, in the absence of this legislative protection, it is not responsible. I should also point out that, as a public carrier in the delivery of reserve services, OTC has no control over who its customers will be and thus has no capacity to limit the risk. That is really the essence of it and I make that clear for the record once again.
Amendment negatived.
Bill agreed to.
TELECOMMUNICATIONS BILL 1989
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 2, after subparagraph 3 (a), insert the following new paragraph:
``(aa) promoting and maintaining effective competition between persons engaged in the commercial supply of telecommunications services in Australia;''.

This amendment provides for the insertion in the charter of Telecom Australia, by way of an expansion of the objects of the Act, a paragraph which would lead to a more pro-competitive outcome. It seems odd to us that the objects of the Act should include a whole range of matters, including ensuring the basic service, maximising efficiency, achieving the highest possible levels of accountancy, optimising rates of expansion and modernisation, enabling all sectors of the telecommunications industry to participate effectively and promoting the development of other sectors of the economy through low prices. But nowhere is there any commitment to competition. We see this as an indication that the Government's ideological slip is showing. It clearly regards competition as a dirty word.

The forces that drive the Australian Labor Party are obviously much more interested in notions of efficiency because they can be achieved behind public sector walls. To talk in terms of competition frightens the troops because it means that competition can derive from outside the parapets. That is anathema to many sections of the Labor Party. Nonetheless, we do not regard competition as an ideological tool. It is simply good sound commonsense. It got a very grudging mention in the second reading speech of the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray). We see no reason why it should not be included in the objects of the Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment is opposed by the Government. It ignores the proposed complementary relationship between Austel and the Trade Practices Commission. It is clear from the Government's May 1988 policy statement that the Trade Practices Commission has the primary role of promoting and maintaining effective competition in all industries. Austel will work with the Trade Practices Commission to promote fair and efficient market conduct in relation to the supply of competitive facilities and services. To this end, the Government will appoint two members of Austel as associate members of the Trade Practices Commission. It is also the case that the proposed amendment ignores the clear statements of policy intent elsewhere in the Bill, especially subparagraph (a) (ii) and paragraph (c) of clause 70.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 2, clause 4, definition of ``basic telephone services'', line 41, leave out ``, subject to the regulations,''.

Our second amendment involves the removal of the expression `subject to the regulations' in the definition of `basic telephone service'. We can understand why the Government should want to define the basic telephone service and provide for a monopoly on it. But to allow for regulations to undermine the notion of basic telephone service, or expand beyond recognition the definition of basic telephone service, defeats the whole purpose of such a definition. It seems extraordinary that `basic telephone service' cannot be simply defined. To say that it means `subject to the regulations, a public switched telephone service', is really a concession that the Government at some stage will want to introduce a backdoor definition by way of regulations that will dramatically expand the concept in a way, no doubt, that the Australian Democrats would fervently support and in the way that the Commission for the Future was toying with until it saw reason some time ago. It seems to us that there can be no justification at all for the inclusion of that phrase. I invite the Minister to explain why it is necessary.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is necessary for the Government to have power to use the regulations here so as to respond quickly to any technological changes relevant to the basic policy of the Government-that is to say, a continuation of Telecom's role as sole provider of the first telephone for three years, with a review of that policy to be completed by 31 December 1990. I need not remind the Committee that any regulations must be consistent with the legislation, particularly with clause 35 (a) of the Bill which makes the Government's stated policy very clear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Alston is correct when he imagines that the Australian Democrats would support, where appropriate, an expansion of the interpretation of the term `basic telephone service'. I stress the words `where appropriate'. Clearly, the Opposition would like a restricted definition of `basic telephone service'. This clause gives comfort to the Democrats in that, if it becomes necessary, as the Minister has said, not just through technological change but particularly through change in the perception and needs of the community, then it is important that movement be possible. Obviously, this amendment is designed to restrict the definition. The Democrats would not want to do that. More importantly, it is clear that the public would not want to do that.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind Senator Alston that there is already some evidence that the public is far ahead of the coalition in this area. There is constant movement in the public's perception of what is basic in telecommunications. That is occurring all the time as new technologies are diffused into the community. As legislators we need to take that into account. What is a standard service in 1989 may well be seen at a later date-perhaps not too late a date-as being substandard. Therefore, we do not support this amendment and find this part of the Bill a considerable comfort.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find the statement made by Senator Powell, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, both enlightening and breathtakingly myopic. It seems to me that what both the Government and the Democrats are saying is that it is proper for the Government to bypass the Parliament in redefining the most basic concept in this Act. If we leave out `subject to regulations', the phrase `basic telephone service' is defined in such a manner that it would have survived over the last 80 years. There have been a number of improvements in switching techniques as a result of technological changes. But at no stage has there been any movement away from the notion that a public switched telephone service supplied by Telecom to a customer by means of a telephone handset that does not have switching functions is not appropriate as a basic item. I could well understand why the Government would want to stick to that definition. It is a definition that has stood the test of time. To allow it to be emasculated and transformed, if the Democrats have their way, simply in response to political pressures whenever some tinpot outfit thought it was a good idea to have some bigger and better free service provided by government in the run-up to an election campaign, is a total abdication of responsibility on the part of any government.

SPEECH.PARA: If there comes a time when the community, through the proper processes, decides in the parliament that it is necessary to expand that definition of `basic telephone service', I would welcome the opportunity for that debate to take place. But to think that somehow by sleight of hand, by electoral pressure applied by people such as the Democrats, the Government can convert the definition in a way that might ultimately be unrecognisable is an affront to commonsense. It is a concession on the part of the Democrats that they are not interested in the proper political processes, that they see anything that might have a vote in it, anything that might allow them to give another free hand-out at some stage, as the proper way to go. We reject that absolutely.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I should say for the record that, as sympathetic as I am to the general policy stance that has been articulated by Senator Powell on behalf of the Australian Democrats, I think possibly the Democrats are reading a bit more into this clause than the structure of the Act will bear. The expression `basic telephone service' appears in only one place in the Bill-that is, in clause 47, in the context of the exclusive right of Telecom, pending the review in 1991 to supply that basic service. The particular concern that the Government has is essentially with the technology involved-specifically, the technology of the handset which is the sort of thing which is capable of changing quite rapidly. It is something coming on to the market which might not satisfy, for some reason, the description in the definition of a telephone handset that does not have switching functions. We may have something which does need a little bit more careful regulatory description to make clear whether it comes within that definition. Essentially that is the reason why this definitional clause has been expressed as it has rather than that the Government wants the flexibility to address some of the larger policy questions that may arise. Having said all that, I do not resile in any way from the basic points that Senator Powell has been making about the thrust and the policy flavour of this legislation on which we see eye to eye.
—I am indebted to the Minister for that explanation, but it raises more questions than it answers.
—No.

—It is the Minister's fault because as he has directed my attention to the fact that it is relevant only to clause 47, I find it extraordinary that one can seriously suggest that there might be sufficient technological developments occurring over the next two years to warrant a change by way of regulations. After all, if we are to take the Government at face value, the first phone monopoly is to be reviewed. That is what the May statement said. I have no doubt that the unions will not allow that in due course. But on the face of it, that clause is a commitment to review. If that is the case, how can one possibly suggest that there could be a need in the next two years to change that basic definition when it could simply be done in the course of the review and, subsequently, in the course of amending that section. Does the Minister contemplate anything at the moment?
—No.

—Is he seriously suggesting that there will be such technological developments over the next two years that we cannot await the outcome of that review which has, as I recall, to take place at least six months before 30 June 1991?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —In this industry anything is possible; things move very quickly. I appreciate that that is a bit hard for the Opposition to grasp here as elsewhere, but we have grasped it and want to guard against that contingency.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Page 6, clause 10, lines 34 to 38, leave out the clause.

This amendment will remove the definition of common interest. This is a matter that hopefully, will be, looked at by Austel in the not too distant future-that is if the Government's structural adjustment committee has not already had its way and gutted Austel by way of reducing its budget, on which basis advertisements have appeared in the daily press. If its staff is to be cut back in the way that reports suggest and its budget is reduced even further, unless there is some windfall profit that derives from the fees that will be imposed by other complementary legislation, Austel simply will not have the capacity to give proper attention to this matter which is a very significant one.

We take the view that private networks should be allowed to flourish. The reason that they are flourishing to date is that it is becoming increasingly attractive for large and small corporations to bypass the basic network because of the overpricing that exists on long distance routes. That is clearly consistent with the experience in other countries as I indicated yesterday in my speech at the second reading stage. The American experience since 1984 indicates that long distance rates have fallen by about 40 per cent. So clearly there are enormous incentives for each of Telecom's 200 largest corporate customers to install their own private networks, and they are doing it in droves. This common interest provision is a desperate measure to frustrate the pace of change, to introduce artificial concepts and barriers to what would otherwise be a very significant move in the direction of rationalisation that would allow private networks to share capacity, that would allow customers to ensure that they use every element of the transmission process. But under the common interest group provision, one has to go through a series of hurdles designed to demonstrate that somehow there is a community of interest between users. That is an anti-competitive device-nothing more nor less-which means that the Government's approach to private networks is neither fish nor fowl because on the one hand it allows them and on the other hand it is doing its best to restrain them. We see that as a very unnecessary and artificial approach to take. Can the Minister give an assurance that, irrespective of the outcome of Austel's funding, it will be able to undertake this review in the very near future and that it will then report in such a way that the results are made public?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes the amendment. It would negate the announced policy position of the Government, that is that the common interest group policy of Telecom should continue at present but be the subject of review by Austel and report to government. Any review of the common interest group policy raises extremely complex issues. It is of vital importance to the carriers because of the implications for the viability of the reserve services and for the operators of private networks. There are important efficiency considerations, but a balance must be struck between what could be seen as competing policy interests. It is the clear intention of the Government to retain the policy role in setting this balance. Austel's review of the common interest group policy will provide ample opportunity for all sectors of the industry to put a view on how the policy shall operate in future. I am not in a position to spell out further than that how that review will be conducted at this stage but, obviously, it will be sensitive to the various currents of opinion that do exist on this subject. There will be ample opportunity to debate the review and its implications before anything arising from it is set in concrete.

—The Australian Democrats do not support this amendment. We feel that the situation as carried forward by the clause in the legislation is important, particularly in the interests of the viability of the carriers of the public network. This amendment is an example of the Opposition's wish to enable the eyes to be picked out, if you like, of those profitable sectors of the telecommunications industry. With Senator Alston's amendment it is possible to envisage a build-up of private networks way beyond the current level, and the degrading of the public network to a situation of haves and have-nots to which we are opposed in this instance and in the whole process.
—Will the Minister give an undertaking that the results of the Austel review on the common interest group policy will be made public?
—Yes.
—Good. By what means and at what stage will Austel's report to the Minister be made public, or will the Government simply give a potted response at some later stage?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator has an affirmative answer; he should not push his luck. I am not the Minister for Transport and Communications. The Minister will behave with his usual sense of responsibility and courtesy.
—I assume that the Minister has some basis for telling us what the Minister for Transport and Communications has in mind and what commitment he is giving. I ask the Minister to amplify that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —There will be a full and open consultative process. Submissions will be taken and there will be a published report. That is the Government's intention. The timetable of it, and the precise modalities, as we say in my new Department, have yet to be resolved. However, there will be ample opportunity for the honourable senator to wax as indignant and as lyrical as he likes for hours on end, and I hope I am not in the chamber when he does.
—Does an open approach mean a public hearing?
—It is up to Austel; go and lobby them.
—Does the Government have any objection to Austel conducting a public hearing?
—No.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3a) Page 23, subclauses 73 (2) and (3), lines 8 to 12, leave out the subclauses.

Amendment No. 3a would remove the power of the Minister to give directions in relation to the common interest group policy. Again, we see no reason at all why the Minister should be intruding into the area. If Austel conducts its policy review in the not too distant future and reports back to the Government and, hopefully, the public, there will be an opportunity for the public at large to judge the balance that should be struck between the competing interests which Senator Evans talked about. To allow the Minister to simply give directions would mean that the Minister could override Austel, make the common interest group policy even more restrictive than it is at present and, effectively, negate the whole notion of competition that currently exists between private networks and the basic network.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been made perfectly clear from the outset that the Government retains the basic policy role in relation to these common interest matters and the balance that necessarily has to be secured. The Government accepts that responsibility. The legislation merely reflects it. The response to this point made by Senator Alston, and on the review of that process over a period of time, is exactly as it was in the preceding amendment, and I have nothing more to add.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder what the Government has in mind in relation to clause 73 (3) which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister shall give to AUSTEL a direction under subsection (2) before the end of one month after the commencement of the section.

In other words, clearly there is a contemplation that in the very near future the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support will tell Austel what to do. Is that simply a mechanism for ensuring that the inquiry goes ahead and, if so, why is it needed by way of legislation?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —This clause is worded in this way in order to guarantee a degree of certainty as to what everybody is up to pending the review. The Government has made it clear in a statement that the common interest policy of Telecom Australia would be maintained pending the review, and this will be formalised by a direction to that effect, I understand, within the time frame which the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) has spelt out, in order to formalise in an Austel context the present practical situation in a Telecom context.
—Is it right that the direction will be confined to the review to be undertaken by Austel?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —The direction will make it clear that the status quo is to prevail pending the holding of that review.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Page 8, after paragraph 18 (a), insert the following new paragraphs:
``(aa) promoting the general objects of this Act;
``(ab) promoting and maintaining effective competition between persons engaged in the supply of telecommunications services in Australia;''.

Amendment No. 4 involves a mechanism that would expand the general functions and responsibilities of Austel to include, firstly, promoting the general objects of the Act and, secondly, promoting and maintaining effective competition. We regard this amendment as of fundamental importance. If Austel is merely in the business of administering and regulating then it becomes part and parcel of the bevy of players who constitute the Telecom Australia preservation society. I am sure that it does not want to do that. I am sure that Austel and its Chairman designate regard its legitimate role as promoting competition in the best interests of Australian consumers. They are not in the business of protecting anyone. Therefore, in our view it would be of considerable comfort and support to Austel to be told, firstly, that it is in the business of promoting the general objects of the Act, which is a very common provision as the Minister will well know and recognise; and, secondly, that Austel should be given a pro-competition charter. If it does not have that, it will clearly not be able to act in the best interests of consumers, it will simply be the lackey of the Government or, worse still, simply looking after the interests of Telecom.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —These proposed amendments are unnecessary. The first is totally superfluous and the second ignores the complementary relationship that Austel will have with the Trade Practices Commission, which I adverted to in response to a previously proposed amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Alston's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (5) Page 8, paragraph 20 (a), line 23, leave out ``and''.
(6) Page 8, after paragraph 20 (a), insert the following new paragraph:
``(aa) regulating the manner in which information relating to customer use of reserved services is controlled; and''.

Amendment No. 5 is a machinery provision. Amendment No. 6 would add a new paragraph to ensure that the functions of Austel include `regulating the manner in which information relating to customer use of reserved services is controlled'. This is a very important amendment because it ensures a level playing field to stop Telecom misusing information it might derive from its reserved services or using it to unfair advantage in the competitive services area. The Australian Democrats for a change should face up to whether they believe that a monopoly is a licence to exploit or whether a monopoly is to be conducted on certain terms which are fair to all. If it is the latter then a monopoly should involve certain obligations, one of which is not to misuse information or to take advantage of it to advance its own competitive service areas.

Therefore, the function of Austel should be to ensure that there is a real Chinese wall in place, that there is no economic cross-subsidy, that the arrangements are transparent and that Telecom is not able to take unfair advantage. The Democrats are not interested at all in the notion because, I suppose, it is over their heads. If the Democrats know anything about cross-subsidisation, they will know there is a distinction to be drawn between social and economic cross-subsidisation. Economic cross-subsidisation is frowned upon by the Trade Practices Commission and anyone else who is interested in competition. It is about ensuring that others do not misuse their monopoly position. That is what this amendment is squarely about. It will be interesting to see whether the Democrats understand that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposed amendments are unnecessary. They ignore the specific provision in clause 68 (2) (c) and the extremely broad powers provided in clause 68 as a whole. Austel has sufficient powers to require all relevant information on reserved services to be published and to regulate the terms and conditions under which information will be provided to participants in the market. Clause 20, particularly when it is read in conjunction with clause 68 (2) (c), is broad enough to provide the necessary guidance to Austel, in the Government's judgment. We oppose the amendments accordingly.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Alston's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (7) Page 10, subclause 29 (3), line 12, leave out the subclause, insert the following subclause:
``(3) Notice of a direction under subsection (1) shall be published in the Gazette within 21 days after the direction is given.''.
(8) Page 10, after subclause 29 (3), add the following new subclause:
``(4) The Minister shall cause a copy of a direction under subsection (1) to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 10 sitting days of that House after the direction is given.''.

Clause 29 currently provides that a direction given by the Minister to Austel shall be published in the Gazette. A direction to Austel is a very significant document, one that we believe should be given maximum public exposure. For it simply to be published in the Gazette would mean that it would become the province of those who spend their lives reading Government gazettes, but of very few others. It may be the Government's intention to ensure that the matter did not come to the attention of the media and others until some time later. We regard that as undesirable. Notice of a direction should be published in the Gazette within 21 days after the direction is given and the direction itself should be tabled in the Parliament. In that way, the Parliament will have an opportunity to debate the merits of the direction. Presumably it will then be able to ascertain from the Minister what created the need for that direction.

As the clause is presently worded, it can only give rise to the suspicion that the Government and its advisers are anxious to avoid the glare of the parliamentary process by having something get only a one line mention. I should retract that, because subclause (3) requires the direction itself to be published. I presume we can take that at face value and that there would not simply be mention of the direction, but publication of its contents. It seems undesirable that it should be confined to the archives in that way.

We urge the Government to reconsider the matter. Presumably it is interested in public debate. I would have thought the Australian Democrats would also have been interested in public debate. Unless the Democrats are prepared to give the Minister carte blanche, they would also be interested in having this matter put squarely into the parliamentary and public arena and not tucked away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —It ought to be appreciated that the really significant policy directions relating to things like value added services and customer premise equipment and so on are subject to parliamentary disallowance procedures. The directions we are talking about here are of a lesser order of significance altogether. As the clause says, they are essentially matters relating to the performance of Austel's functions and the manner of the exercise of its powers rather than the substantive decisions themselves. They might cover, for example, such matters as an equal employment opportunity policy or an industrial democracy policy to be applied by Austel in its internal administration. One would have thought that the particular mechanism that is here proposed for ensuring that those sorts of directions get into the public domain is perfectly adequate for the purpose. It is a time- honoured provision elsewhere around the system to require gazettal. That triggers public attention for those interested in these matters.

SPEECH.PARA: Parliamentary procedures are such that it is possible to pick up and bring to public attention in the Parliament anything that offends anybody in this respect, but the nature of these provisions are such that those kinds of offences are not likely to occur. We can understand the concern for parliamentary exposure and debate for the big policy issues, but this is stretching too long a bow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps students of the arcane and the abstruse might be comforted by that, but I do not read subclause 29 (1) as confining the Minister's directions to equal employment opportunity policies and the like, although I have heard it said on a number of occasions. Certainly that has been the basis of discussions in the course of the draft Bill considerations. Nonetheless, on its face, that would allow some fairly wide-ranging directions to be given to Austel. We can all assume that the directions will be given on non-controversial matters, but they could equally be given on highly controversial matters. It all depends on the length of the chancellor's foot.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Minister takes the view that the exercise of Austel's powers requires it to conduct only one public hearing a year, what does it do-cellular mobile television services or common interest group? I would have thought that the provision is open to a very broad interpretation. If that is the case, one should not distinguish it from the other explicit policy directions that might be given. No good reason has been advanced for why it should not be tabled in the Parliament. We are not saying it should be a disallowable instrument, but simply that the Parliament should be in a position to know as soon as possible what is going on.

TALK.START.PARA: —We do not support the amendments. It cannot be claimed that publication in the Gazette of the Minister's directions in relation to the functions of Austel and the exercise of its powers is, as Senator Alston said earlier, burying it away from public gaze, or whatever term he used. The Gazette is the proper place for publication of such directions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome confirmation by the Australian Democrats that they are not interested in having these matters the subject of parliamentary debate, that they are interested simply in having them tucked away so that neither they nor we will be in a position to know what is going on until some time after the event. It is a clear confirmation that they are prepared to give the Government carte blanche. They are not interested in the merits of the policy issues that might arise under the clause. We will strenuously pursue our amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Alston's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (9) Page 11, subparagraph 33 (1) (c) (ii), line 7, leave out ``and''.
(10) Page 11, paragraph 33 (1) (d), lines 8 to 11, leave out the paragraph.

These amendments would delete clause 33 (1) (d). Clause 33 relates to a policy statement of the Government and defines in various ways the areas of responsibility and the areas of protected services. Subclause (1) (d) provides:

that the shared use and resale of simple carriage of communications over private telecommunications networks should continue to be restricted to prevent undue diversion of communications from public telecommunications networks.

This provision goes to the heart of competition in the area. Private networks have grown up in response to the overpricing on the long distance routes. Australian consumers currently pay 20 to 30 per cent more than they need to. In the United States, for example, the figure is probably closer to 40 per cent. That is certainly the size of the reductions that have been achieved in recent years. Those reductions do not flow through in this country because Telecom Australia not only has a monopoly over the shared use and resale of the simple carriage of telecommunications traffic but also has the benefit of very restrictive provisions that provide for a common interest group policy in relation to the use of private networks. This clause would delete that prohibition on the resale of shared capacity in the same way that the Swedish and British governments are presently doing. Senator Gareth Evans will know from the Office of Telecommunications bulletins, that I have no doubt he continues to receive, that Oftel is considering this matter very carefully and is in the process of implementing its own recommendations because, after all, it is a toothed tiger and it believes that the most effective way of introducing competition into the system, of making the most efficient use of telecommunications capacity, is to allow for the resale of shared capacity. Until such time as we do that in this country, we will have surplus capacity going to waste because of these artificial and restrictive barriers that are put in place as a result of government policy decisions.

The amendments would simply free up the system and allow the most rational use of the telecommunications network. It would allow the use of shared facilities and it would therefore help to drive down those subscriber trunk dialling call charges more towards cost and, in that way, contribute very beneficially to the efficiency of the network. Unless and until that happens, we simply have to say that Telecom will remain a tiger in a cage, not of its own choosing but because those in the Government are too scared to let it out into the jungle where it would thrive, and are therefore not interested in achieving the optimum pricing structures for consumers. We move the amendments in the hope that the Parliament will make it clear that, at least in the way that this Bill is framed, Telecom's monopoly services should be kept to a minimum, the opportunities for competition should be maximised and the most efficient use of the network will result.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —These amendments are totally unacceptable to the Government. The Opposition seeks here to remove from the Bill quite a basic tenet of the Government's policy decisions, that the shared use and resale of capacity over private networks should continue to be restricted. To allow unrestricted shared use or resale would permit the operation of competing common carriers in the Australian telecommunications industry and require a massive upheaval in Telecom's tariffs for leased lines, not to mention the damage that would be done to Telecom's ability to fund its community service obligations through the cross-subsidy. These are all familiar propositions that have been the subject of long debate. I think it would be tedious repetition for me to track through them again. These amendments raise the issues squarely, and they are unacceptable.

—I hear what the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has to say. I understand the supposed rationale for this unacceptable level of protection but can the Minister indicate what the projections are as to the use of shared use and resale of basic network facilities if this sort of provision were deleted?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is self-evident from the language of the statute. I am not going to get into an extended technical discussion of how that would be expected to operate in an environment where the prohibition did not exist. The policy issue is perfectly clear. It was spelt out in the May statement and the extended documentation accompanying that. I have nothing further to add. It would only prolong the debate unmercifully and not change the Government's policy position, as Senator Alston well knows.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to say that the major reason for the Australian Democrats not supporting this amendment is its potential to damage the ability of Telecom Australia to cross-subsidise-a process which we are strongly in favour of, as I have said previously in this debate-and also the potential damage to the public network itself by this sort of action.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are addressing the Bill as a whole. Before we move on to Senator Alston's next amendments, I would like to ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade a question with regard to clause 21, which has passed us slightly, on the issue of the price cap mechanism. If it is appropriate, I would like to do that now. In my speech in the second reading debate I expressed concern that the Government has decided to operate from a single basket. That is, of course, in contrast to the May 1988 statement by the then Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Gareth Evans, in which he said:

SPEECH.PARA: There will be separate price control formulas for residential and business customers. The residential formula will limit both the increase in the average price of all standard services and the change in price of standard access charges.

Last week we had a statement from the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) on price capping. In my speech in the second reading debate I expressed concern that the process which has been decided upon might not be the most appropriate. I think it is worth commenting that it might have been more appropriate to defer the question of the number and composition of the baskets until Austel had been formally established and, with any luck, a consultative process was able to be developed so that we are certain that the decision has been made appropriately. However, that decision has been made. Having looked at the Minister's statement and been somewhat dissatisfied, I wonder whether the former Minister, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, can justify that decision a little more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I addressed Senator Powell in relation to that problem in my reply in the second reading debate yesterday. I do not know whether Senator Powell was in the chamber at the time or has had an opportunity to look at what I said. I can only repeat now, in answer to her question, what I said then. For reasons of administrative practicality, the Government decided to combine the standard services for both sectors-business and residential-into a single basket subject to a common consumer price index-X control, as announced in the ministerial statement on 1 June.

SPEECH.PARA: My own ministerial statement back in 1988 foreshadowed that there would be separate formulas for the two sectors because, at that time, it was believed that that was the best way to limit the permissible change in the residential rental charge. However, we now believe that this objective is better implemented by placing within the one price cap formula a specific limit on permissible increases in the residential rental charge. I said a few other things in and around that subject but that is the essence of my response on that. We believe it addresses the policy concerns that Senator Powell has expressed on this issue. It is a matter of first thoughts not necessarily being best thoughts as one works one's way through the difficult administrative implementation phase of the package.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to that matter, I heard the explanation of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade last night and I was not impressed. Apart from some assertions about having decided that it was administratively more convenient to combine the two sectors, I heard no justification for the change. I invite the Minister to make public any advice that he has received from the Department of Transport and Communications or elsewhere that would indicate where the task force went wrong in the considered judgment it made about the desirability of separate price caps and also to spell out what the consequences would be of a combined price cap. The way things are at the moment, given that the government business enterprise (GBE) statement did not even advert to the fact that the Minister had ignored his own advice, one is left with the suspicion that this is intended to muddy the waters to enable, within that single basket, changes to take place that will not be detectable and will allow for a considerable rebalancing without identifying whether it comes primarily from the residential or business component.

SPEECH.PARA: I would have thought that the policy reason that drove the task force to make the recommendation it did was that it thought it highly desirable to have transparency between those two components so that residential consumers were able to assess whether their local call rates had gone up by any, and what, amount and the extent to which their local call rates might come down accordingly. Business presumably spends a lot more on long distance calls, proportionately and absolutely, than do residential consumers. I would have thought that the two were discrete groups deserving separate treatment. If the Minister is not prepared to make available any policy argumentation, one is forced to conclude that this is a deliberate blurring of the concept.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will bring that invitation to the attention of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis), which is what Senator Alston asked me to do. In due course the Minister may find it possible to give a more detailed response to the quite complex issues which Senator Alston has raised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make it clear that, while it appears that Senator Alston and I might be expressing the same concern, as usual, it is for opposite reasons. Our concern about the single basket relates to a quite different range of issues. For instance, we would say that perhaps it is appropriate in the circumstances to charge different prices for different goods demanded by different groups of consumers. Business places higher peak demands on the telephone system and the infrastructure, the basic network, must be available to meet those peak demands. Charging in a way which takes account of a telephone system with a large peak capacity can be justified. We can also justify in a number of ways keeping the price to members of the general public below the actual cost of providing that service. One justification is that each individual subscriber coming into the network brings a benefit, not just in terms of the calls that he makes but also in terms of the calls which he receives, which increases the use of the network and, therefore, its efficiency. As the percentage of the population with a phone increases, so does the value of having a phone.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Alston has talked about a muddying of the waters. Those are the sorts of issues we would be concerned about in a system which lumps such very different groups together and which, unfortunately, might lead to prices being set perhaps on a basis that does not best advantage those who might need a different system of pricing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make it clear that what Senator Powell is adverting to is what I think is now a discredited notion of social externalities that somehow suggests that when one has 94 per cent household penetration rates, as we do in this country, there is a measurable benefit that flows to existing subscribers. It is simply nonsense. Where one has a very low level of penetration, as there is in many Third World countries, quite obviously if one is able to install telephones in remote areas one can suddenly transform the accessibility of the service.

SPEECH.PARA: That is not the case in Australia. There are something like 650,000 new connections each year. The rate of household formation is almost entirely in the city and metropolitan areas. The idea that, somehow, this has got anything to do with price caps I find quite extraordinary. So our concerns are simply that it is necessary to be able to understand the differential treatment that will be applied within that single price cap. Let there be no misunderstanding: I am sure that the Government is not for a moment suggesting that it will treat those two separate classes of consumers equally; it will not. Whilst the Minister ruled out timed local calls the other day, he certainly made it clear that he expected to see some rebalancing take place. If that is the case, we want to know whether that rebalancing is equally affecting those two separate consumer groups.
I seek leave to move amendments 11 and 20 together.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (11) Page 11, paragraph 35 (a), lines 20 and 21, leave out the paragraph.
(20) Page 15, clause 47, lines 22 to 26, leave out the clause.

Amendment 11 seeks to delete clause 35 (a), which again relates to a policy declaration and, in particular, that Telecom should continue as the sole supplier of the first phone until at least 30 June 1991. This is one of the great scandal areas. The task force itself was well aware of the cost to consumers of the first phone monopoly. It has been estimated to be of the order of $250m a year by way of loss of revenue. This derives from the fact that there is considerable overstaffing and overmanning in a whole range of areas, particularly in rural and remote areas but also within the customer access network.

Anyone who has the misfortune to need a telephone connection will know that it is extraordinarily difficult to obtain it as soon as one would want it. The technicians always have an excuse for not being able to install the service straight away. I even had a personal experience of my own several weeks ago where a fault occurred in the local exchange. Because Telecom did not have me recorded as a member of parliament and, therefore, some sort of higher being, I was merely classified as low level domestic. I am not objecting for one moment, but I rang up as an ordinary consumer and was fobbed off. I was told, `We will report the fault and it is to be hoped that it will be rectified this weekend'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Promote that man.

—I thank the Minister. I pursued the matter after 24 hours when nothing had happened and was then told that the practice was not to do anything about faults over the weekend for low level domestic, which is what I was classified as. Ninety-nine per cent of the population is classified as low level domestic.
—It ruined your self-esteem.
—No, it did not really. This happened at a fairly sensitive time: I was waiting for all those telephone calls of congratulations; I also wanted to make telephone calls to a whole range of people.
—Just as well you were not lobbying that weekend.

—Indeed, and it would have been critical if it had been two weekends later when my preselection came up. I could have blamed Telecom if I had lost my opportunity to continue to annoy Senator Evans on this matter. The fact remains that Telecom has this archaic policy which is designed to cater for technicians who do not want to work at weekends, of if they do they want to be paid triple time.

SPEECH.PARA: Unless one is put on the VIP list, one does not rate. It seems that if one rings up and says that one is a member of parliament, one is put on the special list. But Telecom does not even have the nous to go and check who should be on that list. It does not put all doctors or all members of parliament on the list as a matter of course. It waits until they complain and, in effect, pull rank. If one rings up and says, `I am Mrs So-and-so and my phone is out of order', it says, `Too bad, see you on Monday'. If one says, `My name is Mrs Jones and I am a doctor', it says, `Well, your phone still won't be fixed until Monday, but next time around you will get instant treatment because now we know that you are a doctor and that you are complaining, we will put you on the special list'. That is an outrage. There is no reason at all why an outfit making a net operating profit in excess of $1 billion should not be able to fix our phones when we want them fixed.

That is systematic of the problem with the first phone monopoly, which comes about because the technicians want to have exclusive rights to install, supply and maintain the first phone when there are obviously many technicians, either ex-Telecom employees or others, who are eminently well qualified to do the job, who would do it, presumably, much cheaper because they would be providing a competitive service, who would be prepared to work at weekends and after hours and who would meet the needs of the customer. That is what this is all about. The task force itself was highly embarrassed to be forced to come up with this compromise proposal that Telecom should continue to be the first phone monopolist until at least 30 June 1991. It at least had the decency to suggest that the matter be reviewed. But there is absolutely no reason why we should presume that the unions would allow any review to have a positive outcome. So what we are looking at is probably a fairly successful stalling operation which will result in Telecom maintaining the first phone monopoly in perpetuity or, should I say, until the next election, which is a very different time concept.

Amendment No. 11 seeks to delete Telecom's first phone monopoly immediately. There is no need for a phasing out period. This would result in benefits to Telecom itself. Telecom would not have to carry all the technicians and others who are employed to maintain the monopoly in place. It has been suggested that this might even result in a reduction in staffing of the order of 10,000 people. None of those people would be out of work. A lot more work would be readily available to them. Such a move would also save Telecom heaps, probably something in excess of the $250m in welfare costs that have been estimated by the Australian Institute for Public Policy and others. In this context, I regard such a situation as a national scandal. It causes massive efficiency losses, it is indefensible in terms of policy commitment to efficiency and, therefore, it should be removed immediately. It does nothing to preserve the monopoly. It does nothing to provide an increased capacity to deliver the cross-subsidies for the whole range of deserving beneficiaries who presently receive it. It is simply a burden on the system, it is an imposition on Telecom and it is supported by this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition proposes in amendment No. 11 and in amendment No. 20 to refuse to continue the first telephone monopoly of Telecom, as Senator Alston has indicated. It was a clear decision of Government that Telecom should continue to have the sole right to supply the first telephone, at least until 30 June 1991, so as to ensure that the industry development arrangements (IDAs) applying to first telephones could be implemented. Opening first telephone supply to competition, in our judgment, would mean that it would be impossible to make the industry development arrangements work and it would threaten the massive investment of the Australian manufacturers in plant and equipment associated with the new touchphone 200. The industry development arrangements and the continuation of the first phone monopoly are designed to give the local industry time to adjust from a regime of high protection to one more appropriately based on full participation in the international marketplace.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition's approach threatens the future of the industry in this respect. We oppose it for that reason. There is much that one can say backwards and forwards about the merits, looked at separately and independently, of the first telephone question. There may, indeed, be some aspects of Senator Alston's concerns with which I would not strongly disagree. But this particular clause must be looked at and these matters must be looked at in the context of the IDAs to which I have referred. In that context, there is no question but that these two amendments must be opposed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did you add the words `at least'?
—What does the honourable senator mean by `at least'?
—When you said, `the first telephone until 30 June 1991' you added `at least'.

—I think what Senator Evans had in mind was that it was a section which applied in relation to that period ending on 30 June and such further periods as are prescribed. But the interesting thing is this: if Senator Evans raises the IDA arrangements which involve a five-year phase-out, is he really saying-which is what Senator Lewis has properly raised-that `at least' will mean at least five years and not just the two years that the clause purports to limit it to?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —We want it to be a genuine review of the pros and cons of the first phone monopoly. One does not do that if one sets a restriction which makes it absolutely certain that it will be phased out or removed from that date. It is the intention of the Government to approach this with a totally open mind about how the issue should be handled. But until that time, we will not foreclose the outcome of the review process which would be involved in any language which was more absolute than that to which I have referred.

—In other words, the Minister does not see any difficulty in the removal of the first phone monopoly three years ahead of the expiration of the IDA arrangements? There is nothing inherently contradictory about those two events, is that so?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Maybe not, but the pros and cons of that must be addressed at the time. I will not foreshadow or pre-empt the outcome of the consideration of that very point.

—I am not asking the Minister to pre-empt. I am delighted that he has an open mind, that he is tabula rasa and all those wonderful things for which he is noted. However, could I simply ask that the responsible Minister should indicate whether there would be any contradiction in terms if one were to remove the first phone monopoly three years before the expiration of the IDA arrangement?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ELECTORATE: (Victoria Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will once again draw that invitation to the Minister's attention.

—On behalf of the Australian Democrats, I point out that we are not supporting these amendments on the basis of our support, at this point at least, for a continuation of the first phone monopoly. We understand the importance of the first phone monopoly to Telecom and in particular to the industry here in Australia. The Minister made a very brief reference. It is of concern to us that in this whole debate Telecom's local purchasing policy seems very much to have dropped off the agenda. Given our balance of payments problems, I would have thought that that would be an issue to which we ought to have been addressing ourselves more directly in this whole debate.
