TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. I refer the Minister to the death over the weekend of the witness, Mr X, whose evidence was so critical in the successful prosecution of former South Australian police Chief Inspector Moyse. Is it a fact that Mr X died as a result of a drug overdose which is a common method used in the disposal of drug case witnesses? What is the effect of the death on the 11 arrests made subsequent to the completion of the Moyse matter on the basis of evidence provided by Mr X? What is the effect of the death on the National Crime Authority (NCA) investigation in Adelaide of 56 named persons bearing in mind that the State Deputy Premier has said that the allegations are at least, in part, derived from the Mr X transcripts? Is it not a fact that the NCA had advised Mr X that there was a contract on his life? Why in such circumstances did he cease to be a protected witness?

—I know nothing of the death of Mr X. I was not aware that he had died, let alone of the circumstances outlined by Senator Hill. I might say that I am rather annoyed that I have not been briefed in respect of that death. As far as protected witnesses are concerned, as Senator Hill will know, on occasions even those who are offered protection do not take it up. I am unaware as to whether indeed that was the situation in regard to Mr X. It may well be that he, as in the case of many other witnesses, chose not to have to undertake the regime which is applied to the protection offered by the Australian Federal Police on behalf of the National Crime Authority. But to be quite frank, I know nothing of the matter and will seek to obtain a very full answer.

—I direct a question to the Minister for Resources. Is the Minister aware of reports of allegations by the Minister for Mines, Energy and Northern Development in Queensland that there has been a 50 per cent reduction in gold exploration as a consequence of the Federal Government's decision that the gold mining industry should pay the taxes applied to all other industries? If these reports are correct, can the Minister inform the Senate whether the allegations accurately reflect the condition of the industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen reports attributed to Mr Martin Tenni, the Queensland Minister for Mines, Energy and Northern Development. He blames the Federal Government for a reduction in exploration for gold in Australia. I must say I find that quite an extraordinary allegation coming from him because he presides over a tax on gold which is a pernicious tax in its own right. It is a tax either on the production or, if the profit level is high enough, on profit. It is a State royalty tax which, if he is concerned about taxes as a deterrent to exploration, he has it within his power to remove entirely and provide a stimulus for exploration. Of course, he has not done that. One must view the allegations he makes from the point that they are hollow if he does not propose to put his actions where his mouth is.

ANSWER.PARA: The truth of the matter of gold exploration is that we intend to make the activity of gold mining subject to normal company tax which all other industries in Australia are required to meet. To describe it therefore as a gold tax is taking a liberty with the English language because it is a tax on companies; it is a tax on gold mining. The royalty that I referred to a moment ago that applies in Queensland is in fact a gold tax. It is not the one that we are applying. The figures for exploration according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics are that exploration for gold mining was down in 1988 not by the 50 per cent that Mr Tenni referred to but by 18 per cent. By contrast I note that gold production is 45 per cent higher in the March quarter this year than it was in the previous March quarter. Gold is now among our top four export earners. It earned Australia $2.4 billion in 1987-88.

The major reasons for the variation in exploration is that the world price of gold has fallen quite dramatically over recent months. The price has been falling in that sense since 1980. In January 1980 the price of gold hit $US850 an ounce. In January 1988 it was down to $US480 an ounce. Earlier this year the figure descended to between $US375 and $US400 an ounce. That reflects a decline in the value of gold on the world exchanges. That is the reason why there has not been a positive incentive for exploration. It is not the introduction of a tax on the companies that mine gold that this Government would wish to introduce. I would have thought that Martin Tenni would have understood the situation in terms of pricing.

As I have said, the Government decided in the May economic statement in 1988 that the exemption would end because there is no economic or other justification for it. It was a unique instance of a blanket exemption for an entire industry and for its entire income. Senator Walsh has often made the point that a significant proportion of overseas ownerships figures in gold mining ownership in Australia. The result is therefore that the exemption from taxation that these companies enjoy in Australia is transferred to overseas dividends. These dividends are taxed by foreign governments and thus they get the advantage that the Australian government should get.

As I have said, the Queensland Government imposes its own tax on gold. If the Queensland Minister is concerned he should do something about that. I might say about the Queensland tax on gold in the post-Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct situation in Queensland where Premier Ahern is saying that all things are now open, all things are now transparent, that Queensland still remains the State in Australia that does not reveal how much it earns from gold taxation. I have estimated it through my Department at about $5m a year in royalties. But there is nothing on the public record which discloses openly and in a way in which the community can check what in fact the Queensland Government earns in gold mining income. If it is an open and accountable government one would have thought that at least it would have done that.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. It relates to a report in today's Canberra Times in which the Prime Minister has admitted that interest rates are destined to remain high, in his words, `for a while'. Does this comment by Mr Hawke represent an honest and very public about-face on the promise of falling interest rates which Mr Hawke gave prior to the Western Australian election? Is the Minister prepared to give the many thousands of Australian home owners struggling under these interest rates some idea of just how long `for a while' might be? I note that the Prime Minister has also revealed that if he were in the same position as those having to run a family home under these record interest levels he would be hurt, angry and looking to take it out on the Government. Does this comment by Mr Hawke indicate the Government's support for the increasing number of protests against it which are occurring around Australia over the interest rates issue? In particular, does the Government support some of the proposals being adopted by those meetings such as an interest rate cap?
—I have not seen the Canberra Times report.
—You don't want to see it. You know what the Prime Minister said.
—I do not know what the Canberra Times report is saying. In fact, I rarely read the Canberra Times. There is one column in it that is worth reading.
—Ian Warden.

—Yes, but I had better not say any more about that. This must be about the fifty-second time that the Opposition has referred to some comment that the Prime Minister made some time in the dim past. It is a bit worn out. I have, of course, been asked to speculate about the likely duration of interest rates at present levels. I believe I have consistently, ever since we have been in government, refused to speculate in the Senate or outside the Senate about likely movements in interest rates. That is a habit I do not intend to break now.

—Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade give details of the results of the Polish elections? Does the Government believe that the results are a true indication of the views of the Polish people? Is there any indication that the Polish Government will refuse to accept the results? If so, will the Australian Government make strong representations to the Polish Government to accept the will of the Polish people?

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I fail to see how the internal results of those elections in the terms of the question as asked are a matter within the Minister's portfolio. The Minister has widespread expertise. If he wishes to have the question rephrased in terms of the implications for Australian foreign policy, fine, but I think that we should spend a little bit of this Question Time on Australia's domestic concerns and not on matters which are not within this Minister's province.
—Mr President, on that point of order, the question that I am asking is: What will be the response of the Australian Government if the Polish Government refuses to accept the result of the elections?
—Order! There is no point of order. It is within the Minister's area to comment on any elections in any country. It is clearly a matter of foreign affairs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make it clear for the record that I am hearing the question for the first time. I did not draft it. I wish to God I could draft some of Senator Schacht's questions! I am able to respond briefly on the subject of the Polish elections because they are a matter of major international interest. The outcome of those elections, the first round of which took place on 4 June, involves the first in postwar Poland in which genuine alternative candidates to the Communist Party's nominees have been allowed to stand in some 35 per cent of lower House constituencies and for the newly created Senate. The initial reports suggest that in the context of those elections Solidarity has gained a majority of votes in the constituencies it has contested and that many of the party officials holding senior government posts may not be elected. It is, in fact, a pretty stunning result as has been widely acknowledged in the media reports this morning.

ANSWER.PARA: Electorates in which no candidates gain a clear majority in the lower House will go to the polls again for a run-off between the most successful candidates on 18 June. Of course the Australian Government welcomes those elections in which the Polish people have had some real choice for the first time and of course we would be seriously concerned if the process of introducing political pluralism into Poland were to be retarded in any way. There has been some speculation about that. I think it is premature to go further than to acknowledge the existence of that speculation. If there were to be action of the kind that has been feared in some quarters that would obviously involve a fundamental human rights question once again in respect of which it is entirely appropriate that other governments around the world express their views. Obviously, the internal situation in Poland has a larger significance as well for the stability of the Eastern bloc as a whole; and indeed, as a result, for the whole of Europe.

Finally, I find it quite extraordinary that Senator Chaney should have intervened in the way he did to suggest that there was something inappropriate about this question being asked. I am sure that Polish community members here will take very closely into account that reaction that has come from the Leader of the Opposition as demonstrating a grotesque insensitivity on his part.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs although it may be that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has carriage of this matter at the moment. I refer to the current situation in China and ask the Minister whether the Government has any contingency plans to deal with a significant rise in requests for political refugee status from the thousands of secondary and tertiary students from China currently studying in Australia and from the thousands of Chinese students who, while not formally enrolled in any institution, are undertaking studies at the request of the Chinese Government or party organisations. Upon what basis will the Government decide as to the refugee status between one student and another, given the indiscriminate killing currently under way in China? Have any applications currently been received with regard to political refugee status from any students studying in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —My colleague the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has already expressed to the Chinese Ambassador the Government's deep concern at the response of the People's Republic of China (PRC) Government to political demonstrations by PRC citizens. The Government is closely monitoring the situation in the People's Republic of China as it evolves and the implications for PRC nationals now in Australia. The Government has decided to extend the temporary entry permits of PRC nationals legally in Australia as at 4 June. Applications should be made at any Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs office around Australia. Temporary entry permits will be extended until the end of July within the same category as the applicant currently holds, such as student visa or visitor visa. This will allow a breathing space while the situation in the People's Republic of China becomes clearer.

ANSWER.PARA: It is still too early to talk definitely about refugee status in Australia. I must stress again that events in the PRC are still unfolding and accordingly the Government is not in a position to give its final response to the serious situation there. The Government will consider the need for any further policy response in the light of the situation as it evolves. There are a number of visas which have been issued to persons who have not yet arrived in Australia. At this stage we intend to honour all valid visas. The current situation in Beijing means that immigration activity in the Embassy will be spasmodic. It is my intention that these activities will return to normal as soon as possible.

Applicants will be treated like any other applicant for refugee status. Applications will not be determined on the basis of a class of people, but on individual merits. They will be considered on the basis of individual claims. It has not been brought to my attention yet that anyone has applied for refugee status, although in some cases I would not think that that would be long in coming. It is estimated that some 15,000 people from the People's Republic of China are in Australia. Of those, 4,000 are visitors, 476 are on temporary permits, 10,600 are on student visas and there are 300 others, totalling about 15,405. If there were a substantial application rate we would need contingency plans to deal with them. The current system for processing onshore refugee claims, which amount to between 500 and 700 a year, would obviously have to be revamped.

I suggest that it is still a little early to say what the situation is, but we will meet our international obligations under the 1951 United Nations Convention relating to the status of refugees and the 1967 protocols. We have no intention of not meeting them. I cannot predict what will happen in China; there may even be a change of government. I have no idea what the situation will be down the track.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

—Is leave granted?

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. The Government should be applauded for its initiatives to continue its commitment to environmental issues. However, while individual behaviour towards concern for the environment must be encouraged, most major environmental pollution is caused not by individuals but by industry. What steps can the Federal Government take to address this area, particularly in the face of the State governments' principal responsibility for relevant legislation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —In the earlier part of Senator Crowley's question she compared what individuals contribute to environmental difficulties with that contributed by industry. While it is true that in the big picture industry is contributing a great deal, it is not really appropriate to minimise the contribution that individuals can make in terms of repairing damage to our environment, in particular when one looks at water quality. The experience in the United States has shown-the best example is the city of Los Angeles, which has some of the worst environmental problems in the world, particularly with air and water pollution-that programs designed to encourage householders to take more care and concern with the environment can have extraordinary effects. The city of Los Angeles is even now phasing out the use of backyard appliances that use petrol. It has a program that is much wider than anything that has ever been envisaged in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: The poster which the Government, in conjunction with the Australian Conservation Foundation, has sent out around Australia to mark World Environment Day contains 20 ways in which ordinary householders can assist with these problems. They include such simple things as turning off taps while cleaning one's teeth and using fluorescent lights rather than electric lights because they obviously use less energy. There are a whole number of programs which can be used by ordinary householders.

When one comes to industry, obviously it becomes more difficult. The three main ways in which the Commonwealth gets entry into the environmental field at present have been through the external affairs power, via World Heritage, through export controls, which we have over a number of issues important for the environment, such as sand mining, where we are always getting into some arguments, and through advice over foreign investment about which we have had one argument in very recent times. There are very few ways in which the Commonwealth can get into the act. In recent times it has been suggested that we ought to use the corporations power to do that. We have received opinions a number of times which suggest that there are ways of frustrating the corporations power, which makes its use by the Commonwealth somewhat difficult. Nonetheless, I will seek yet another opinion, given the current interest in that issue, to see whether it might be possible. In the event that it is not, then either we have to keep extending the three entrees that we have now, or we have to look some time in the future, particularly with the problems which the greenhouse phenomenon will bring to Australia, at increasing Commonwealth powers via a referendum. It is something I floated some weeks ago but which I suggested was some time off.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not going to save this Government.

—Nothing will save Senator Boswell. I think we should continue to examine that possibility, given the absolute need for it, because we have the hillbilly antics of governments like that in Queensland, which Senator Boswell follows so closely, which cause so much damage to our environment and which must at some stage be stopped.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Further to the Minister's answer, I ask: To what extent is it reasonable for the Minister to pursue discussions with the relevant State Ministers with a view to cooperation if we cannot do anything by legislation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite obviously, cooperation is what we have been trying. It works with some States but it does not with others. Some States, such as Queensland, will only get better with a change of government. Other States, such as Senator Crowley's State of South Australia, are among the more enlightened.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. It concerns the tragic events in China and the safety of Australian citizens there. Has the safety of Australian students and academics at the Beijing University been established to the Government's satisfaction? Is the Australian Embassy in Beijing available for and being used as a sanctuary for any Australians who fear for their safety? Further, as the Government has advised Australians to leave China, and as the airports have been swamped, is the Australian Government making other arrangements to evacuate Australian citizens?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Embassy in Beijing has been in very close contact with Australian students in China for the duration of the crisis there and is presently confident that not only all the Australian students but all Australians in Beijing are safe. Yesterday, 5 June, the Embassy collected some Australian students and brought them to the Embassy. Certainly, the Embassy will be permanently available as a sanctuary should that become necessary. The current travel advice issued by my Department advises that all travel to China should be postponed until further notice. It also advises that non-diplomatic Australians in Beijing should leave as soon as flight bookings can be arranged.

ANSWER.PARA: We are presently giving consideration to further upgrading that advice in the light of the continuing very tense, very volatile and potentially very dangerous situation in Beijing. We are giving consideration to means by which diplomatic dependants, non-diplomatic staff and other Australians in Beijing might be able to be got out if the situation deteriorates further and if it proves difficult to get international airline bookings out of there. This is under very active and constant review at the mission level in the Embassy and at the level of departmental consideration and in consultation with other relevant departments, Qantas Airways Ltd and so on here in Australia. Beyond that I cannot really report in any more detail as to what the situation is except to say that we have it under very close review.

It is not only the situation in Beijing that is giving rise to concern; it is also the situation in other parts of China. Tensions in Shanghai are very high at the moment with reports of large demonstrations and blockades-as yet, no military action, and we hope very intensely that this will be maintained without further violence and bloodshed breaking out. Similarly, there are reports from other cities of similar tension. As yet, there are no reports from elsewhere of military action, and again we hope that that will continue to be the case.

More generally, we have sought assurances from the Chinese Government about the safety of Australians. That was part of my message to the Chinese Ambassador, Zhang Zai, in my conversation with him yesterday. I am now able to advise the Senate that the Ambassador was able yesterday to see a senior official from the office of the Chinese Minister for Foreign Affairs in Beijing to communicate to him in detail the Australian Government's response, including the full text of my message to the Ambassador yesterday, and in particular, to communicate our concerns about ensuring the safety of Australians in Beijing. The reply on that particular question-the subject matter of Senator Chaney's question to me now-regarding the safety of Australians in China, was that they would be safe so long as they strictly abided by the rules of martial law. That may or may not be regarded as a satisfactory response. Certainly, we are concerned about the situation and we are giving close consideration now, as I have said, to further upgrading the advice and the action we will be taking to ensure that it is possible for people to leave China.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. I refer to the computerised fuel efficiency device known as a metromiser, which was developed by the South Australian Institute of Technology. Is the system being examined by the Melbourne Metropolitan Transit Authority for its trains? Have any potential fuel savings been recorded using the metromiser? What was the role of the Commonwealth Government in the production of the device?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have seen the article in the Melbourne Age of 25 May under the heading `Device could let Met coast to fuel savings'. It refers to what Senator Maguire has referred to in his question, the metromiser, which is a device that has been developed by the South Australian Institute of Technology from research grants that the national energy research, development and demonstration program (NERDDP) has provided since 1985 totalling in excess of $530,000. Those grants have enabled research to go into the development of fuel conservation systems for railways. It has been led in this case by Associate Professor Ian Milroy whose research team is developing two systems under what they call the metromiser concept.

ANSWER.PARA: The metromiser will improve the fuel efficiency of urban train systems. In fact, 30 Adelaide trains are expected to be operating on the system by July. The long haul metromiser is for non-urban systems. Fuel savings of between 10 and 25 per cent have been achieved, with expected payback periods on installation costs of as little as two years for the suburban metromiser and one year for the long haul metromiser. Since the savings are in fuel efficiency-particularly on the Victorian system for which they will be used, which is an electrified system-there are real savings in energy output by the instrumentalities generating electricity. Since they are coal fired generators, that adds to a reduction in coal fired energy which I think all of us are pleased to see.

Professor Milroy and his team are to be congratulated for their achievement because, besides the local benefits that accrue, successful trials of this system are being undertaken in Canada and it would seem there are further export opportunities available. Improved management and conservation of energy and the funding of projects such as this are high priorities for research, development and demonstration under the national energy research, development and demonstration program. In the transport area alone, $15.1m has been provided for research, development and demonstration methods of traffic and transport management leading to fuel efficiency, conservation and substitution for petrol and distillate in vehicles. That is a major aspect of NERDDP. While I am on that subject may I say that the draft Liberal-National Party resources and energy policy, under section 6.4 which has the heading `Research', states:

Assistance to the electricity sector provided by National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Program will be reviewed. Australian research institutions will be encouraged to undertake commissioned research into the electricity sector.

The word `review' is often a synonym used in these terms for `cut out'. I hope it is recognised that the role of the NERDDP is to find other methods of fuel efficiency for energy conservation, and to reduce our reliance on petroleum as a fuel. Although I do not have any expectation that the Opposition will ever be in power, I draw attention to the fact that if ever it did get there it would reduce these sorts of programs.

—I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. How does the support of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, for the deportation of the Chilean activist, Mr Sergio Buschmann, on the grounds that he was actively supporting the armed overthrow of the Chilean Government and because he, the Minister, found this repugnant and insupportable-in this he was unreservedly and unequivocally supported yesterday by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Senator Robert Ray-square with the Government's attitude to the presence of activists of the African National Congress in Australia when this organisation is committed to the armed overthrow of the South African Government?

—First of all, the honourable senator should check what the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade said yesterday in relation to the Chilean activist, as he describes him, and get his facts right about that matter. Secondly, in relation to the presence in Australia of members, as the honourable senator put it, of the African National Congress, that is an issue which is peculiarly within the responsibilities, I suspect, in terms of foreign policy, of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. —My question is directed to the Minister for Consumer Affairs. Is it a fact that the product safety and recall provisions of the Trade Practices Act have been in operation for almost two years? Can the Minister indicate whether these provisions have been invoked in a sufficient number of cases to justify their introduction?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Devlin's question goes to the heart of one of the most basic elements of consumer protection in this country, and that is the protection of consumers from unsafe goods and products. As well as doing that, there is a need to ensure that the market is kept in a healthy, competitive environment, free of such unsafe products and goods, so that competition is as equal as possible. To this end, the Trade Practices Act is pivotal in protecting consumers from unsafe goods and products. It does so by adopting a national, effective regime of recall and product safety provisions; it does so by protecting people against unsafe goods; and, as I say, it does so by a comprehensive, national recall system. As Senator Devlin has said, this system has been in operation for almost two years-in fact, it has been in place since 1 July 1986. I should note, at this point, that the system was introduced and passed through this Parliament despite the objection of the Opposition. It should also be remembered that the provisions apply only to goods supplied after that date. Despite the fact that the system has been in operation for this limited period, and has applied to this limited range of goods, it has had quite an extensive operation.

ANSWER.PARA: We are talking about a regime which provides mandatory standards of quality for goods to meet. Those standards are imposed nationally and uniformally. There are also provisions which allow for individual goods to be declared as unsafe. This assessment is made on the judgment of whether they will, or may, cause injury to individuals. The first step in that process is an interim ban, followed by a permanent ban if the Government is sure that such goods will cause those injuries. In addition, and importantly, an immediate ban can be imposed when there is imminent risk of death or injury because of the unsafe product.

The Government's policy over the last two years has been to embark upon the voluntary recall process as the primary alternative. The Government believes that the best way effectively to ensure total, if not substantial, recall is with the cooperation of industry. Voluntary recalls have been our first step. We have often used the immediate ban process as well as a mandatory recall, if there is inadequate compliance with the voluntary recall that is often arranged between government and industry. I should also say that these powers have been used with care and on the advice of experts in a whole range of fields. We have informal arrangements with State electricity authorities when it comes to unsafe electrical goods. We also have these sorts of arrangements with the Department of Transport and Communications and the Department of Community Services and Health when it comes to vehicles and therapeutic goods respectively. The main area of food and consumer goods is governed by the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs.

There has been a great degree of success in the utilisation of these provisions. In the period from 1 July 1986 to 25 May 1989 there has been a total of 560 recalls. Of those, general consumer goods amounted to 99, electrical goods 34, foods and beverages 17, motor vehicles, parts and accessories 117--

TALK.START.PARA: —Put out a statement.

—The number of recalls in respect of pharmaceutical and therapeutic devices-a most important area, which may not bother Senator Hill-amounted to 291. We are talking, therefore, of 560 recalls. I should also say, to complete the answer--
—But if the Minister--

—I can understand Senator Hill having no interest in this area at all as the Opposition opposed these provisions, but the Government thinks this has been a pivotal provision in protecting consumers in this country. For the sake of completeness, I should say that in terms of pharmaceutical and therapeutic devices, the provisions have operated at a pivotal stage, that is, before these goods have reached the consumer. In summary, I thank Senator Devlin for his question. The Trade Practices Act has been used quite extensively to protect consumers and to ensure that the market place acts fairly not only for consumers but also for competitors.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Has the Minister received an explanation of the latest `lock up Tasmania' proposals from his Tasmanian colleague Michael Field? Are the additional areas of forest now proposed to be set aside in the accord, from present and future commercial use, in line with the final agreements reached between this Government and the previous Tasmanian Government? I further ask: in view of the huge loss of State, business and personal income this would incur, could Tasmania expect to have such losses made up by an equivalent annual Federal funding allocation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, the arrangements made between the incoming Premier of Tasmania, Mr Field, and Dr Brown differ from the arrangements made between the Commonwealth and the Government of Mr Gray. The Commonwealth, not having control over all forest areas is, of course, not in a position to dictate at its whim whatever its will might be. My colleague, Senator Cook, is responsible for those negotiations.
—Don't blame Cookie.

—I am not blaming Senator Cook. I am not criticising him at all; I am stating a fact. Senator Cook negotiated an agreement with the Tasmanian Government. A new Tasmanian Government will come to power. As I understand it, the agreement that has been created now allows for logging in six of the nine National Estate areas which were referred to by Senator Cook in the agreement that he had with the Tasmanian Government. Studies will be carried out in all of those areas to determine what alternatives to logging there are for them in the future. The question of compensation ought not to arise because Mr Field and Dr Brown are quite convinced that in the interim there will certainly be enough timber to go around. In the long term, what we are about is establishing just what resource there is which would enable the State of Tasmania to take pressure off National Estate forests.

—My question, which is also directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, and follows Senator Crowley's question, but goes much further, relates to the Page One program last evening on which the Minister claimed that the powers that the Commonwealth possessed to control environmental damage were too limited and that he had legal advice that the exercise of that power could be easily circumvented. I ask the Minister: What constitutional rights are guaranteed to the States under the Australian Constitution, especially with regard to the environment? Secondly, under what constitutional power did the Commonwealth prevent the Tasmanian Hydro-Electric Commission building a dam? Did the decision of the High Court of Australia in that case not depend on constitutional power contained in section 51 (xx) of the Constitution? Could the Minister explain in outline how the Federal environmental protection legislation under section 51 (i) and section 51 (xx) might be circumvented?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am certainly not qualified to give Senator Coulter a legal opinion. That would be crazy. In respect of the first part of the question as to what constitutional rights are guaranteed to the States, there is quite a considerable argument amongst constitutional lawyers as to what they are. I would refer the honourable senator to, I think, section 100 of the Constitution which deals with inland waters. My recollection is that there is considerable disagreement as to whether even a power like that amounts to reserve power. I am not qualified to resolve that debate. The honourable senator asked under which constitutional power had the Commonwealth prevented the Tasmanian Hydro-Electric Commission from building a dam. If one goes back to that case one will find that the Commonwealth argued powers under section 51 for race, acquisition of property, external affairs and corporations, which is quite a range of powers. In answer to the third part of the question, the decision of the High Court depended, in part, on the corporations power. I will not outline how environmental protection legislation under section 51 might be circumvented. The last thing I wish to do is to give people a blueprint as to how they might get around future action to be taken by a Commonwealth government. I have already indicated that I intend to seek a further opinion on the use of the corporations power. I do not intend to make legal opinions available in the Senate. I doubt that the Commonwealth ought to weaken its own position in future cases by advertising what it will do.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is it not a fact that the Commonwealth has extensively used powers under section 51 (i) and section 51 (xx) to control a wide range of things and that the Government, therefore, has the power in the environmental area but is simply loath to use it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I doubt very much whether too many honourable senators opposite would suggest that the Commonwealth has been loath to use the environmental power over time.
—Right over the top!

—When States deserve to be run right over the top of, we certainly have done so. Senator Coulter exaggerates in claiming that powers have been extensively used. Those powers have been used and in cases where they are appropriate. In some cases, I am advised, they are easily frustratable; so I have been reluctant to push on with them. I intend to seek yet another opinion on that particular question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I claim to have been misrepresented. During Question Time Senator Sheil made the extraordinary suggestion that I had made some public statements supporting the Chilean Mr Buschmann's deportation from this country on the ground of various political characteristics and activities upon which he had embarked. I have had quite a lot to say about the naive romanticism of those who think that Mr Buschmann is some sort of freedom fighter against the Pinochet regime. I have said that his weapon is the gun, not the ballot box. I have pointed out the extent to which he has made clear that his commitment is to armed struggle, regardless of the process of democratisation at work in Chile. All of that is clear and on the record. I have been at absolute pains in all my statements on this matter to make clear that none of that has anything to do with the question of deportation.

SPEECH.PARA: For the record I refer to my press release of 2 June 1989 which is in the same terms as statements I made at a press conference during the weekend. It will clarify the matter. It reads:

Mr Buschmann is presently subject to a deportation order signed because of serious breaches by him of Australian immigration law involving a false statement about the purpose of his visit to Australia and failure to disclose his earlier exclusion from another country. That law is being applied by my colleague Senator Ray and the Immigration Department in exactly the same non-discriminatory way as it is to all entrants to Australia, and without any reference to the matters I have referred to above.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a further and better reply to a question asked of me last week by Senator Tambling about Darwin Airport. He was not very happy with the answer that I provided and I can see why, upon re-reading it. I have added some supplementary information that goes more to the substance of his concerns.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The reply read as follows-

Senator Tambling has asked that I supply more details concerning the answer which I incorporated into Hansard on 1 June. This was in answer to a question he asked on 31 May about recent allegations made by Mr McMahon of Ansett regarding a lack of consultation of the Darwin Airport Redevelopment.
While the answer I gave on 1 June was accurate, I am happy to provide more information.

I am advised that according to a report of a person who attended the breakfast which Mr McMahon hosted and addressed, Mr McMahon's basic concern was that a new development of Darwin facilities costing $65m was not justified.

I am told that his position was that Ansett was reluctant to pay for space in a terminal and for facilities which Ansett would not need. He indicated that if charging arrangements at the new Darwin terminal were not acceptable to Ansett, then they would seek to lease land at Darwin for the construction of a dedicated Ansett terminal.

In developing the proposal for new facilities at Darwin, the Federal Airports Corporation consulted with both Ansett and Australian Airlines on the facilities needed and the lease conditions in the new Darwin terminal.
Ansett has written to the corporation seeking exact conditions and rental costs in the proposed new development and I am advised that the corporation will be responding shortly to their letter.

At this stage, the issue is one for the Federal Airports Corporation and Ansett to resolve. I reiterate from my answer on 1 June, the issue of a separate Ansett Terminal Development was not raised in discussions held between Ansett and Australian Airlines on facilities and lease conditions before Mr McMahon made his remarks on 31 May. I have no doubt that if Ansett seriously proposed to build its own terminal, it would discuss it with the corporation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I have an answer to a question which was asked of me in Question Time yesterday by Senator Newman relating to a disability allowance for Australian Defence Force (ADF) members of the United Nations Iran-Iraq Military Observer Group (UNIIMOG). The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following reply. All ADF members serving with UNIIMOG are in receipt of a difficult post allowance. This allowance is paid to compensate members for such factors as adverse climate, isolation, lack of medical facilities, presence of disease, absence of normal facilities, restriction on movement, and local leave problems. ADF members currently attached to UNIIMOG receive $5,780 per annum as difficult post allowance. The determination extending the allowance to ADF members in UNIIMOG was signed on 16 December 1988 and made retrospective to the date of arrival of the first contingent in Iran.

ANSWER.PARA: The Department of Defence, in conjunction with the Department of Industrial Relations, is examining recently received data on the difficulties experienced on the Iran-Iraq ceasefire line with a view to assessing the need for further compensation. ADF members with UNIIMOG are in receipt of $US185 per day from the United Nations to assist with their local payments for rations, quarters and incidentals. In addition to difficult post allowance members receive the following Australian allowances: separation allowance, $3.44 per day; transfer allowance, $335 to $410; and an outlay allowance-an interest-free loan of $1,500. Charges for rations and quarters for these servicemen have also been waived.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —In addition to the answer I gave yesterday to a question by Senator Haines I said that I intended to seek further advice. On the question of Aboriginal concerns, the Department of Aboriginal Affairs advised that it has no knowledge of the suggestion of 200 sites of Aboriginal significance on the Beecroft Peninsula. Defence is aware of 25 sites on the peninsula, 90 per cent of which are middens. Of those sites 70 per cent have already been disturbed and the environmental impact study on relocation of the facilities to Jervis Bay will extensively address Aboriginal concerns. The only Aboriginal site in the impact area of the exercise under question is called the drum and drumsticks-some rocks which are out to sea. They have not been used as a target since 1986 when the Aboriginal community notified the Department of their significance as a sacred site. There are no other sites of which the Department has knowledge in the impact area.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to the history of the Beecroft Range, it has been used as a bombardment range for 50 years. The range was in use as recently as over the last couple of weeks for naval gunfire training. HMAS Torrens on 29 May, 31 May and 1 June 1989, and HMAS Brisbane on 30 May 1989 fired a total of 100 five-inch shells. No complaints were received on the occasion of those firings. In terms of regular use, 70 naval gun support serials per year are held over 60 days. That amounts to a total of 930 rounds into the impact area over the year. There are 100 serials per year by the Royal Australian Air Force. That will be increased as the F18 comes into service. Most of those use cannons although there are some bombs. The Army's involvement includes rapier surface to air firings and artillery firings as required.

Between January 1986 and the end of March 1988 the Beecroft Peninsula was closed to the public for these purposes for 193 days. The peninsula is used about seven days a month. This exercise is hardly a great shock or different from the way in which these exercises have been conducted in the past. In terms of community consultation, a public meeting was held in Currarong-the settlement closest to the range-on 10 May 1989 to provide local residents with information about the exercise. Aspects of the exercise such as night firings have been tailored to minimise public inconvenience. A media release was issued before the commencement of the exercise, a copy of which I will table. I would also like to table a copy of the draft land management plan for the Beecroft Peninsula. That plan which has been in the public arena for a couple of years has been extensively discussed with the Aboriginal community, the south coast environment group, the Vincentia Progress Association, the Shoalhaven Combined Progress Associations, the Currarong Progress Association and the Callala Beach Progress Association. There has been extensive community consultation on that plan.

In terms of public safety and demonstrators, which have received so much publicity today, the impact area of the range is surrounded by a large safety area from which the public is excluded when the range is in operation. In total some 12 demonstrators have been found on the range both yesterday and today. It is believed that some demonstrators remain on the range. The Defence Force is giving the Acting Minister for Defence an absolute assurance that the exercise will not commence until it is certain that no persons remain on the range. The search for remaining protesters is continuing.

With regard to the environmental considerations for the firing, the Defence Force management plan for the range requires that any damage to the range as a result of an exercise is repaired. All unexploded ordnance also is cleared from the range. Given the present wet conditions, the scale and nature of the exercise have been modified to minimise any potential damage. None of the heavier 155-millimetre guns will be used. All guns are being airlifted into and out of the range to avoid the need to tow them over wet ground. The guns will be fired from a prepared hard standing area.

One other thing to mention about Aboriginal concerns is that Mr John Zakharov of the Australian National University is currently conducting a study of Aboriginal law on the peninsula; that will be made available as soon as it comes to hand.

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time Senator Hill asked me a series of questions concerning the death of Mr X, as he is known. I have some answers from the Chief Executive Officer of the National Crime Authority. At his own request, Mr X was released from witness protection on 22 September 1988. At the time of his death Mr X was facing charges in New South Wales in respect of which he had been granted bail. As the Authority understands it, Mr X went to Kings Cross in the early hours of Saturday 3 June and administered heroin to himself. He then went to sleep. At 6 p.m. that day his companion sought to wake him. She was unable to do so and reported the matter to the police at 7.40 p.m.; he was found to be dead. The post-mortem has not yet been held. The death is being investigated by New South Wales police, but as the Authority understands it, at this stage there is no evidence of foul play. On 16 November 1988 the Authority received information that Mr X's life was in danger. He was so informed on 17 November 1988 by an Authority investigator when it was suggested to him that he move from his address at that time and take every effort to conceal his whereabouts. In fact he did not move until February 1989. At this stage the Authority has no comment to make on any implications Mr X's death may have on the South Australian reference.

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The need for the Government to ensure the future of Qantas and Australian Airlines by their sale to the public, as suggested by the Minister for Transport and Communications and supported by the Prime Minister.

This is a very important motion. I am delighted to see that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) is with us today because he will be speaking in this debate. In fact, Senator Evans seconded the motion to refer the whole question of funding of the airlines to a special committee established at the Australian Labor Party (ALP) National Conference last year. That has some significance because it is quite clear that in recent years the airlines have not just been in a holding pattern but have been in a terminal decline. There are some in the Government ranks who are aware of the magnitude of the problem and do not see it simply in desperate political terms. It is very interesting that the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Willis, was finally prevailed upon to come forward on the Face to Face program last Sunday-once again an example of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) leading from behind. He clearly twisted Mr Willis's arm to the point where it was obvious that Mr Willis had to cooperate. We will no doubt see further evidence of forced cooperation from people such as the honourable member for Maribyrnong, Mr Griffiths, whose committee has met, I think, on only one or two occasions and who will now be prevailed upon to come up with something to satisfy his political master. Indeed, so desperate is Mr Griffiths to get himself up front that I have no doubt at all that he will have no ideological difficulties with Mr Willis's proposal.

Credit must go to the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, for identifying the drastic plight of the airlines as long ago as May 1988 when he pointed out, in demolishing some of what he described as the great lies about public enterprise, that Qantas Airways Ltd and Australian Airlines have been net losers for the Government. He said:

The second big lie of the current debate on public and private ownership is that the Government has benefited financially from its public enterprise investments. In the majority of cases this is absolute rubbish. Public enterprise is often a net drain on the Budget and only in rare cases produces a return which is commensurate with the amount of capital tied up in an organisation. Assessed against capital injections using a 6 per cent real discount rate the dividends paid by Qantas and Australian Airlines have produced cumulative net losses for each organisation of $882.1m and $704.8m respectively over the period they have been owned by the Commonwealth.

That is a national disgrace and an absolute disaster, not just for the airlines, not just for consumers, but also for the Australian economy and the taxpayers who have to fund those airlines. Indeed, I think Senator Walsh pointed out that the dividends paid by the airlines in recent years have been about one-half of the capital injections, which in themselves have been modest.

Why is it that economic logic should point inexorably in the direction of the sell-off that Senator Evans and his other economic cohorts would fervently like but the Government has simply been fiddling while the airlines burn? The reality is that there is a vicious factional brawl going on. Unfortunately, Senator Childs has his preselection coming up this weekend, so I suppose he has to make a short term strategic retreat. One can imagine that there will be no shortage of left wing colleagues who will once again ram yesterday's ideology down the throat of this Government. What Mr Hawke is on about is no Damascus road conversion; nor indeed is Mr Willis, one of the most conservative of Ministers and one who has been a `big government is beautiful' ideologue for many years. He would not have a bar of this sort of discussion unless he was persuaded of the desperate plight of the airlines and the state to which the public sector has sunk under this Government. Not only has it been drained of funds but it has also been hung out to dry on the rack.

There is no other explanation of why James Strong left Australian Airlines recently apart from the fact, as the Chairman, Ted Harris, made plain to the press conference, that the airline could not afford to hold him. He took the opportunity at that time to point out--

TALK.START.PARA: —He got a better offer. Have you spoken to him?

—I am going only on press releases and reports. If Senator Collins wants to say they are untrue, he can say so. What Mr Harris was reported as saying, without challenge, was that he could well understand--
—He was one of Bob's mates.

—Indeed, he was, and presumably remains, one of Bob's mates. He made it clear that no-one could blame James Strong, no-one could expect that people would stay in a government owned airline while it was being bound hand and foot by government regulation. Although the salary package has apparently been increased to about $250,000 from the figure paid to Mr Strong of $106,000, even Mr Harris is pessimistic about the prospects of finding an adequate replacement. So these are mere bandaids.

SPEECH.PARA: It is quite clear that Australian Airlines will go from bad to worse. Qantas will not be able to improve its fleet and buy those aircraft that it desperately needs unless it gets that $600m injection that Senator Evans's Caucus discussion paper on government business enterprises made so clear was necessary. That was more than 12 months ago. Once again, nothing has happened. What we know is that Qantas has a gearing ratio of about 80 : 20. It is not a commercially sound ratio. To his credit, Senator Walsh has made no bones about that fact. He pointed out that the approach of the Left-pretending that because a business is in government hands debt-equity ratios really do not matter-is simply another means of protecting the airline from commercial pressures which will inevitably result in its being risk averse. What will happen then is that it will simply get further and further behind. While Ansett is able to swallow up East-West Airlines Ltd, Australian can go nowhere.

As Mr Harris also made clear, if the airline did want to engage in any acquisitions, it would have to go through a whole series of committees; presumably the Caucus committee would be the first port of call because that is what happens under this Government. One does not simply approach a Minister; one goes to the Caucus liaison committee or explains it to the relevant back bench group. If one can get one's way across that hurdle, one might be allowed to see the Minister because one is then in a position to tell him the deal has been done. That appears to be very much what this whole exercise is about. That is why we have had people such as Senator Button and Mr Dawkins coming out in recent days supporting poor old Ralph, who has put his neck on the chopping block.

It is quite clear that the Prime Minister is determined to thumb his nose at the ALP National Conference. The resolution was quite clear-that that special committee was simply to look at public sector funding options and was to report back to the National Conference before any further action was to be taken. Yet I do not think any of us has any illusions that this Prime Minister does not have the courage or the intestinal fortitude to confront a hostile National Conference, that the advice given to him by people like Batchelor and Hogg is clearly that he would not win. Therefore this whole exercise is about circumventing the proper processes of the ALP. If that is what we are on about, I think Senator Gareth Evans should come clean and tell his factional opponents that this is a new ball game, that the Left is not going to get its chance to garner the numbers at the National Conference. What the Prime Minister is on about is finding some way of avoiding that confrontation.

The tragedy is that even if the Prime Minister were to get his way, we would have a very pale imitation of a privatisation policy for this country. It would be one driven by political expediency and by the desperate need somehow to establish some credentials on micro-economic reform, which have been blown out of the water in recent days. The editorial in today's Australian not only makes it clear why the Government cannot afford the airline but also makes the following very true statement:

It is hard to escape the impression that the Government will consider biting the bullet on airline privatisation because it wants to save money, but will not attempt fundamental micro-economic reform that would produce even greater benefits for the community.
Mr Willis has apparently come to the conclusion that it is easier to take on his party than the unions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you read the bit that comes just before that, about the comparisons between this Government and your lot?
—That is what that is all about.
—There is another one, too-our successive micro-economic reforms.
—The paragraph before that states:

SPEECH.PARA: But while Mr Willis should be commended for defying one of the last shibboleths of the Labor Party by calling for the 100 per cent privatisation of Qantas and Australian Airlines, it does not excuse his timid capitulation to the Waterside Workers Federation in baulking at fundamental reform of coastal shipping.
If Senator Collins wants me to read out any other highlights, I am more than happy to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read out the opening of the editorial.
—Perhaps we can read this:

SPEECH.PARA: The case for privatising the government-owned airlines is so overwhelming, if only for the simple reason that the Government can no longer afford to run them, that it is being restrained only by the Labor Party's ideology out of a different era.
What more does Senator Collins want? Is there anything else he would like?

TALK.START.PARA: —Read a few more paragraphs.
—Let me read what Paul Kelly has had to say recently. Unless Senator Collins has a better card to play, I thought Paul Kelly made it very clear what drives this Government. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: A Hawke Government locked by the Party into a rigid opposition to any privatisation is easy to depict as yesterday's government. It can be depicted as a prisoner of outmoded ideology.

Mr Hawke is aware that now is the time for micro-economic reform. Privatisation is a high profile and symbolic issue. The test will be whether the Government retains the will to govern and takes the tough decisions.

There is the statesmanship. After reading editorials and hearing all of the informed commentators in this country telling the Government that there is a desperate need to embark on fundamental micro-economic reform, all we have had are a few false starts, certainly in the coastal shipping and waterfront areas, and now a last desperate attempt by the Prime Minister to get this item back on the agenda once more. I do not know whether he expects some plaudits if he can somehow pull off some compromise, but it is clear it will be against the wishes not only of his Party but also of the many who have reservations about the extent of the motivation for this particular proposition.

If the Government were serious about what Mr Willis is now espousing, it would be done tomorrow. If this Government was able to make decisions on its own account, it would make them. It would not have to wait and do deals behind closed doors; it would not wait and decide whether it can confront or circumvent the National Conference. It would not worry about what the major players in Caucus had to say; it would not worry about allowing people such as Mr Howe to say as recently as March of this year, `I do not think privatisation has any support within the Labor Party'. It would simply take the tough decisions. But, no, it allows policy to be driven by people such as Mr Saunderson, who have long-held and hard-formed views about the undesirability of privatisation. It lets these sorts of debates go on and be agonised over in the community to a point where the Prime Minister is forced to stop the haemorrhaging.

Is that the sort of leadership we want in this country? Is that the way to tackle a critical issue? It is as though the Prime Minister had not read Senator Evans's Caucus discussion paper, as though the Government had not looked at what Senator Walsh has had to say time and again about the desperate plight of the airlines and about the need to demolish some of the spurious arguments that are put forward to justify keeping a whole range of public sector enterprises in government hands. As Senator Walsh says, `The assumption that because an organisation is in public hands it will serve the public interest is fatally flawed'. I think he has been a voice in the wilderness, a voice of economic rationality. Obviously, he is not heeded by this Government unless it gets into extremis, and it is clearly reaching that point now. Paul Kelly has said:

The dangerous gulf over privatisation has reached the point where there is mounting evidence of the inability of Cabinet to manage the Party and pilot through majority positions for its economic reform. Anti-privatisation is not a policy in itself, the issue is the viability of these presently wholly owned government airlines.

This debate has been dragging on for years. That is the tragedy; that is the real political problem that this Government faces. What we are now looking at are some sorts of bandaid solutions that will enable the Government to limp through to the next election. We stress the need for the Government to ensure the future of Qantas and Australian Airlines by selling them to the public as supported-belatedly-by a whole raft of economic Ministers; to recognise not only the political reality but the economic imperative of that outcome; and to recognise that there are no second best solutions, that the painter must be cut, as Mr Willis puts it, and, better late than never, recognise the wider virtues of privatisation.

Of course, the Government has been twisting in the wind on this issue for some years. One has only to go to some of the statements that have been made over the years by various Ministers to see what intellectual contortions they have had to embark upon. It is quite clear that, from people like Mr Keating through to the Prime Minister, there has been a great deal of agonising-not driven, I might say, by any genuine concern about whether privatisation makes sense in economic terms, but simply driven by where the numbers are. Mr Keating, a few years ago in the House of Representatives, said:

No matter where one looks, whether it be at TAA or the other authorities, there is no case for the Opposition's argument in economics except, simply to indulge ideologically in a Thatcherite, vandalistic splurge to try to destroy these authorities . . .
Let us look at the sort of overblown and overflown rhetoric that Mr Keating blows around:

The Labor Party will fight tooth and nail to keep these public authorities in the hands of the Commonwealth. We are about refurbishing them and keeping them strong. We are not about wrecking them and selling them. The great public services they provide will continue to be provided while ever this Government has the breath to defend them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hollow words.

—Wonderful stuff, not only hollow but hypocritical, because since that time Mr Keating has become a silent but supportive advocate of privatising the airlines. He is not prepared to go up front and tell anyone about it, but he just occasionally whispers to colleagues that it is not a bad idea. This is the great economic rationalist. This is the man who found it necessary to say, in Churchillian language, `We will fight while ever this Government has the breath to defend those public enterprises'. That sort of rhetorical overkill will come back to haunt this Government. Mr Hawke adopted the words of former British Prime Minister Harold Macmillan, speaking from the Costa Geriatrica in the twilight of his long and distinguished career. Macmillan talked about selling off the family silver. That sort of expression has been cheaply adopted as though it were somehow an intellectually respectable argument against privatisation. Jumping on the band wagon, Mr Hawke said that privatisation was:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a one-off fire sale; a sale of the century of your assets, the assets of the people of Australia.

In recent times there has been not one word on why he has done that volte face. Of course, the reason is that he sniffed the wind. He is very perturbed indeed that all the intellectually responsible commentators in this country have been urging the Government to take that tough decision, and until now he has not been able to deliver the goods. There is no reason to think that somehow the Government is about to recognise that economic reality. All that it will do is back off. Looking at the terms of an amendment to be moved by Senator Evans, it would seem that even now we have a back-off:
. . . the continued viability of Qantas and Australian Airlines . . . and ensure by the most efficient means their capacity to fund forthcoming fleet expansion.

It is a pathetic come-down. I hope that Senator Evans has the courage to say what he said on television the other night-that he does not change his mind. If a gutless Prime Minister wants to change his mind, let him swing. If the Prime Minister does not even have the courage to withstand the heat since Sunday and to let Ralph Willis be taken to the cleaners by the back bench, let him do it. If Senator Evans has an ounce of intellectual integrity, he will make clear what he has said consistently over the years-that privatisation is an economic virtue and an imperative; that he knows that the airlines must be sold off. If he is now going to have the gall and hypocrisy to get up here and pretend that somehow all can be well by some sort of restructuring, some bandaid, some last-minute injection from the intensive care unit, it is quite clear that Senator Evans's claim to intellectual responsibility is nil. I would have hoped that he would have more integrity than that and that he would simply go through the motions, if he is forced to, in supporting something that clearly has been drafted not by him but by others. But the significance of this, overwhelmingly, is that once again the Prime Minister has thrown in the towel. He has put his foot in the water and been burnt to death. He is not even prepared to stand up and say so; rather, he sends people like Senator Evans in here to try to water down something that the Prime Minister and all the major economic Ministers in this Government were saying was a wonderful idea as recently as yesterday. I very much look forward to hearing Senator Evans's explanation.

That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Button moving an amendment to the motion.
