SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (12) Page 11, paragraph 35 (b), lines 22 and 23, leave out the paragraph, insert the following paragraph:
``(b) that Telecom shall supply, install and maintain public payphones where there is a community need as determined by AUSTEL;''.
(21) Page 15, subclause 48 (1), lines 28 to 30, leave out the subclause insert the following subclause:
``(1) Telecom shall supply, install and maintain public payphones where there is a community need as determined by AUSTEL.''.
(22) Page 15, after subclause 48 (1), insert the following new subclause:
``(1a) Subject to subsection (1), the supply, installation and maintenance of public payphones within Australia is open to competition.''.

Telecom Australia has no need to have an exclusive right to supply, install and maintain public telephones. Telecom endeavoured to persuade the Davidson Public Inquiry into Telecommunication Services in Australia that it made a loss on public telephones of the order of $40m. As I recall it, the Davidson inquiry was sufficiently concerned about the accuracy of that submission to call in, I think, Coopers and Lybrand, which took a contrary view. Since that time Telecom has continued to maintain that this is some sort of burdensome obligation that it bears in the public interest. I do not accept that it must inevitably lose money on public pay phones. There are a number of ways in which it could improve the service and performance of those phones. It is very odd that it has not yet introduced credit cards for public pay phone users in the way that has been the case in the United Kingdom for several years, and certainly in Japan, where telephone credit cards as a personal accessory item are very popular. People will often buy them on the basis that it gives them a credit facility for some hundreds of phone calls in advance. They have become a very good source of revenue for NTT. I see no reason at all why Telecom should not have moved already in that direction other than the fact that because it is a monopoly it does not feel under any pressure to respond to those consumer demands or preferences.

Therefore, I see no reason at all why there should not be competition in the provision of public pay phones. Certainly, Mercury provides public pay phones in the United Kingdom. There is no reason why the provision of these phones could not be subcontracted out to local councils and municipalities. I am sure that private contractors would be more than ready to service them. Vandalism could be significantly reduced as a result of credit card facilities being generally available and not just available to special and frequent users of long distance telephone services.

Our amendment, therefore, is concerned, firstly, with the competition benefits that would derive from opening up that system and, secondly, with one eye to the responsibility to ensure that people in areas where it might otherwise be uneconomic to do so are nonetheless provided with public pay phone facilities. That could be done quite simply by cross-subsidy arrangements, either by way of a levy being imposed on carriers or even by a government subsidy, although I tend to favour the former. On that basis we propose that Telecom should have an obligation to supply, install and maintain public pay phones where there is a community need as determined by Austel. Certainly in the United Kingdom, British Telecom (BT), as I understand it, willingly accepts an obligation to locate pay phones wherever Oftel deems it desirable. The experience to date is that BT very much welcomes the opportunity to achieve saturation coverage in a whole range of rural and remote areas-although that term has a different meaning in the context of the United Kingdom. Nonetheless, the fact is that it is desirable, as a marketing exercise, for the dominant carrier to have that sort of universal coverage. I do not subscribe to the view that if this system were open to competition Telecom would immediately vacate the field or move out of the uneconomic areas. I have no doubt at all that Telecom would be very keen indeed to maintain public telephones around the nation as much as possible, even to the extent that they might cost it a bit on the deal. The public relations benefits would be very significant and I have no doubt that, with the efficiency opportunities that would open up from competition, Telecom could significantly reduce its costs of servicing those pay phones.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposed amendment to impose the obligation on Telecom Australia to supply, install and maintain pay phones where there is a community need is quite unnecessary. Telecom's community service obligation to provide public pay phones will be mandated through the Australian Telecommunications Corporation Bill and Austel's specific powers to ensure that Telecom provides public pay phones when and where they are needed. That is provided by subclause 68 (3) of this Telecommunications Bill. The requirement to provide public telephone services on a universal basis is logically supported by a degree of monopoly in this area. That is the principle of the Bill, it is what we support and, accordingly, we cannot accept the amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments move into the domain of fantasy, particularly when we consider amendment 22. This is the amendment to subclause 48 to insert the proposal which obliges Telecom to supply, install and maintain all public pay phones, subject to its obligations where there is a community need; otherwise the supply, installation and maintenance is to be open to competition. The Opposition is suggesting that the supply, installation and maintenance of public phones should be fully competitive, but where a public pay phone is not provided because the commercial returns are not high enough, Telecom is to be directed to provide the service. Thus, we are confronted with a proposition that Telecom is to fund loss-making public pay phones out of revenue from a fully competitive market; while competitors have no such obligation. That is just a further example of the old maxim which still has so much currency on Opposition benches, `Capitalise your profits; socialise your losses'. The Government rejects this amendment for all the reasons which should be totally self-evident.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats reject these amendments as well. They are amongst the most transparent of the amendments which the Opposition is moving, in terms of the last comment made by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Early in his remarks Senator Alston said that the Opposition does not see why a loss should be made on public pay phones. He went on to move these amendments, one of which provides that in areas where pay phones will make a loss Austel will make Telecom Australia provide those phones. What the honourable senator is really saying is, `Where pay phones don't make a loss, we want them handed over to our mates in the telecommunications industry in the private sector'.

SPEECH.PARA: This is about the best example of what, from my vague memory of primary school history, used to be called blackbirding by the squattocracy. The squattocracy were people who went into the rich Western District of Victoria-from which they have now emerged in the form of the National and Liberal parties, all too often-and picked the eyes out of the areas which were to be opened up by surrounding watercourses and waterholes so that the rest of the land was pretty useless to anyone else who came along because they could not get water. I think that was called blackbirding; it was certainly picking the eyes out of things, and that is clearly what is being proposed in this amendment, as it is in many others in this series of amendments.

It is extraordinary to suggest that one of the ways of making pay phones more profitable and equitable is by the sale of credit cards. I want to know how the inhabitants of Housing Commission flats in North Melbourne are expected to benefit from this kind of exercise. It is clearly the sort of exercise which benefits people in the business community and the better off. As for claims that maintenance could be less expensive for Telecom in a system where the only public telephone booths which would be run by Telecom would be less numerous and probably scattered all over the place, it seems to me it would be a very inefficient system if Telecom only serviced a few sporadic booths in areas of poverty or isolation. Again, bearing in mind that according to Senator Alston in the best of all worlds there would not be the ability to cross-subsidise, and all these costs would have to be upfront at every Budget, I have to ask how much this would cost, and has the National Party component of the coalition really looked at the implications of this exercise?

The Democrats have been critical of Telecom in the past on the question of public pay phones. We are concerned that the provision of pay phones appears to be being reduced in some low socio-economic areas, or in areas where people do not have their own telephones or are moving constantly and awaiting telephone installations. We draw the attention of the Government to that fact, and express our hope that the provision of pay phones in such cases will be regarded as a priority in the future.

I would like to make a personal comment. I often find that the siting of public pay phones is most inappropriate. They seem, particularly in country towns, to be placed on that side of the road where the hot sun will blaze down from midday. I had the experience of almost fainting in a booth one afternoon in a northern Victorian town. Conversely, in southern areas they seem to be placed on the windiest, coldest corners. A more humane approach to the siting of pay phones might lead to more profitability because people might find them a bit more comfortable to use.

I also think that the technology of public pay phones could be improved. I know this is part of the point that Senator Alston was making when he referred to credit card phones. There is a need to improve technology relating to public pay phones. What we see around the world demonstrates that there are better technologies available. With those qualifying remarks, we clearly see-as the Government obviously does-public pay phones as an integral part of the community service obligation, and we would not want to see them taken out of the jurisdiction of Telecom.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is enlightening that the best that the Australian Democrats could do was ask a rhetorical question about the cost of public pay phones. They clearly do not have any real interest in the subject other than to extend the community service obligation involved. So I will ask that question of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade--
—You are the one who is saying who should own them.

—If the Democrats are not interested in knowing what it costs, it is nice to understand that public debate should proceed on that basis. I find the cost an important factor in determining whether there is a burden to be borne by Telecom Australia; whether new technology, cheaper maintenance and a range of other facilities might dramatically reduce costs-not just to Telecom but to the consumer; and, to the point that there is a need for a subsidy, that that subsidy could be dramatically reduced.

SPEECH.PARA: The suggestion that somehow the poor will not benefit from a credit card arrangement strikes me as fairly bizarre, unless Senator Powell is suggesting that some people simply cannot help themselves and need to be protected by government. The fact is that if there is a consumer demand for the product it is not the responsibility of Telecom to deny that demand. In every other area of life there are those who can afford services before others. The fact that the middle classes might be in a position to afford video cassette recorders does not constitute discrimination against the poor, according to my definition of the word, any more than the fact that some people can afford to buy colour television sets when others make do with black and white, even though the latter may be small in number these days. The same goes for any form of new technology. To suggest that somehow that is socio- economic discrimination is cloud-cuckoo stuff. To the extent that the credit card revolution is able to reduce the cost of vandalism and the cost to consumers and taxpayers, I would have thought the Democrats would welcome that. To the extent that it generates surplus revenue which would then be available to improve the technology of blue phones, as we now see them, and other facilities that might be put in place, it is also in the consumer interest. To pretend that none of this brave new world stuff should take place because there might be some people who do not want, or even worse choose not to have, credit cards, I regard as economic and social nonsense.

I ask the Minister when he deigns to return to the table to indicate the accurate and reliable figure for the cost of public pay phones. It is a matter of serious community concern that Davidson was not satisfied on the subject. Presumably, the task force was not able to get an accurate figure on the subject. Again, we are simply asked to accept that this should be an area of monopoly protection when we have no sensible idea of what is involved: whether it needs to be a community service obligation at all; or whether overseas experience does not suggest that there might be a number of people who would be prepared to contract to provide public phones in economic and uneconomic areas. In other words, each individual contractor could accept an obligation to cross-subsidise within its own arrangements. There is nothing particularly novel about that. The Government could simply put out public telephones to tender. Any range of people could accept the tender. Part of the tender obligation is to provide public phones in certain areas determined by government. If some of those are stand-alone profit makers and others are loss makers, so be it. The tenderer has to decide at what price it is prepared to accommodate each of those arrangements. I regard that as rational, sensible and ultimately in the community interests.

I invite the Minister to obtain, not necessarily immediately but in due course, an accurate assessment of the current cost of the pay phones that Telecom presently provides. I hope that we can have a bit more than a guesstimate when, at least, there has been quasi-scientific research done on the subject and that we will be given more than an approximate figure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have specific figures that I can give Senator Alston now. The cost of the pay phone community service obligation is being analysed in the current Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics study on costs, taking into account the cross-subsidies involved. That will be provided in due course. I cannot be more precise about it. We appreciate the significance and legitimacy of the question. I am not being impolite, but there is no point in making these figures up. It has been the subject of a lot of argument over a long time, as Senator Alston would be aware.
—Does that mean there will ultimately be a discrete figure for pay phones?
—That is the hope.
—Is there any reason to think the hope will not be realised?
—I do not believe that Senator Alston will be disappointed.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Alston's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (12a) Page 11, paragraph 35 (c), line 27, leave out ``and''.
(12b) Page 11, after paragraph 35 (d), add the following word and new paragraph:

``and (e) that all telephone users in rural and remote areas should be able to make telephone calls, free of charge, to the nearest regional office of each Commonwealth Government Department and agency.

These amendments would add, after paragraph 35 (d), a further declaration of policy which would make it clear that the intention of the Parliament is that all telephone users in rural and remote areas should be able to make telephone calls free of charge to the nearest regional office of each Commonwealth government department or agency. These amendments are so blindingly obviously designed to accommodate those who might otherwise have difficulty in affording the cost of calls to such agencies as the Department of Social Security, the Commonwealth Employment Service and others that I would have thought the Australian Democrats would find it impossible to oppose them. This will be the acid test: if they are really interested in social equity and social justice, they will recognise the compelling virtue of the amendments. I do not think I need to say much more, other than that there are very many people in rural areas who find a discrimination against them when, quite often out of necessity to make inquiries of welfare agencies and the like, they make what for those in metropolitan areas would be a local call, but for the privilege of which they have to pay a long distance call charge. I am indebted to my colleague Senator Sheil for bringing this matter to my attention. Certainly it is deserving of support by us all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is fully appreciative of the special need of telephone users in rural and remote areas to have direct and reasonably priced telephone access to government agencies. Indeed, Telecom Australia has introduced a regional 008 service in addition to the Australia-wide and State-wide 008 services previously available. This will increasingly provide the means for organisations to be accessible to their rural and remote clients at the local call rate.

SPEECH.PARA: The usage charge to organisations which lease the regional 008 service is less than that for the State-wide 008 service, as one would expect. Initially, the service is available to government departments and government authorities offering community services. It will progressively be made available to business organisations as existing network limitations are overcome, with the aim of its being generally available by 1991. Increasing availability of call diversion and distant exchange line facilities is an additional means, which it is worth mentioning at this point, for services not present in a remote centre to be accessible at a low cost to customers in and around that centre. So, of course, the principle of access is acknowledged and Telecom is doing something about it. The first port of call in doing something about it is creating a mechanism for use by government departments. Given these special arrangements that are already in place and which are being enhanced, as I have indicated, we do not consider it appropriate that we should legislate to provide free telephone calls to certain groups of people.

The Bill does specifically address the means by which community interests can make representations to Austel to ensure that the carriers meet their responsibility to provide access to their reserve services on an equitable basis. That is a further line of call for people who may have some lack of appreciation of the speed with which Telecom is moving to implement the region-wide system in a way that will meet the objectives to which Senator Alston refers. This is another example of just a little bit of grandstanding. We all acknowledge the desirability of the 008 services being applied. They are being applied in practice. The access is there. Senator Alston's amendment is not needed to produce that result.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make an impassioned plea to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) to reconsider-I am not just grandstanding-on the grounds of equity for people. One has to consider that a person in a city can ring the whole gamut of government departments for the price of a local call, but people in remote areas have to pay subscriber trunk dialling (STD) rates to do so and often have to wait, while listening to music, until they get through to the right person. That seems inequitable to me. Also, people in remote areas are really being taxed twice in this instance. The cost of putting up a building in the central business district of any metropolitan area is very high. Telephone subscribers in remote areas contribute towards that building through their taxes. But on top of that, they have to pay STD rates to make phone calls to government departments.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is supposed to service all people. As has been mentioned in debate on a previous amendment, Telecom puts telephone boxes in remote places for the convenience of those people. Just on the ground of equity, I make the plea for 008 numbers to be provided. This was suggested to me by a most perspicacious constituent; it is not just an idea that has been promoted in order to grandstand and get publicity. If the Minister is worried about the cost of it, the equipment is already there. It is rather like the situation when a military campaign is written off. It does not cost any more to provide the service. If there were an additional cost involved, one can imagine that that would be offset by the equity provided to people in remote areas. The precedent has already been set for 008 numbers for the wives of Defence Force personnel. The Australian Taxation Office has 008 numbers, although it is rather peculiar that it may have an 008 number listed in the metropolitan telephone book, but not in regional ones. For example, it is not listed in the Gold Coast phone book that it has a 008 number for Brisbane calls.

I understand that the Minister is saying that technical amendments are being made to improve the system. But I just cannot see, on the ground of equity alone, how the Government could not support an amendment such as this to give the people in the bush a chance to ring at a local call rate government departments that have a high degree of public contact. It is so easy for people in the cities to do that but so much harder and more costly for people in the bush. I cannot for the life of me understand why the Australian Democrats will not support this amendment just on the one ground of equity for rural people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is perhaps an example of part of the debate earlier in this chamber with regard to the question of who benefits and who is disadvantaged by privatisation. Clearly, if the Opposition were to have its way fully with this legislation and in other areas, the scenario would be that people in rural and remote areas would be disadvantaged because, clearly, their services would be the uneconomic ones which, under a user pays system, would cause those users to pay even more.

SPEECH.PARA: As we have already heard from honourable senators on both sides of the chamber, there are measures under way to increase the use of 008 services. I believe that those measures are supported by everybody in this chamber. It is interesting to ask a question that I have asked before, but this time I ask it of the Opposition. Has the Opposition costed this proposal-that is a question often asked of the Australian Democrats-and is there any perception in the moving of this amendment of the economic costs, since most of the other amendments we have been given here have been put on that basis?

I have had personal experience of the cost of contacting most of the government departments which are not as yet using the service. Many of my constituents in rural areas who have to contact government departments, such as the Department of Social Security, rather than just the local regional offices-for example, in times of emergency-have found that it has become a much less expensive exercise since the extension of boundaries for subscriber trunk dialling (STD) calls and since those calls to community centres have been made on a more rational basis. Being conscious of costs, many departments call back clients who have left their names and given their numbers. I think this is something which could be done in the meantime. While it is important to encourage the development of the sort of process which is taking place, I do not believe it is an area in which we should legislate. We must accept the fact that the technology is under way and that it is a process which will be implemented by government departments as they find it necessary. It is already being implemented, as Senator Sheil has said.

We should also encourage more offices of governments to become more regionalised. On that principle there would be fewer costs. Normally the more heavily used client contact departments, such as the Department of Social Security, the Department of Community Services and Health and so on, are regionalised to a greater degree. Given the STD boundary changes and the community call changes which have taken place, the impost for most people is not quite as high. I have contacted some people in the remote areas where it is high, and they have told me they have had no problem in getting the Department to call them back so that they could then discuss their problem at the Department's expense, which is clearly what the amendment is designed to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think I have ever heard such woolly thinking as that which we have just heard from the Australian Democrats. I also believe that the stance taken by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) has been totally inconsistent. For example, would the Democrats knock back a 008 number to the electorate offices of senators if that was what was offered to them to enable their constituents to make appropriate inquiries? Let me assure honourable senators that that offer has just been made to me by the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West). It has also been made to a number of honourable senators who need to service people from rural and remote communities. In order to service our constituents' needs properly a 008 number will be installed in our electorate offices in the near future-in fact, those negotiations are currently under way. The Minister for Administrative Services has authorised it, has accepted the need for it and has in fact put it in place.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Powell mentioned that there were a number of service phone numbers for various departments that already need to utilise the 008 facility. We are well aware that such needs arise for rape crisis centres, women's referral centres or social welfare oriented organisations and groups. Most of those receive a Commonwealth government subsidy for their operation, and the Government is happy to pick up the cost of the installations in that regard. I believe that this is a matter of consistency. The Government should accept that there is a need for servicing the community. The proposals that have been promoted for some time by Senator Sheil, both through questions in this place and through notices of motion, and in a number of other proposals, can only mean an improvement of government services and answerability and accountability to the community generally.
I certainly support the amendment moved by Senator Alston, which states:
That all telephone users in rural and remote areas should be able to make telephone calls, free of charge, to the nearest regional office of each Commonwealth Government Department and agency.
I believe the amendment stands on its merits. It should stand on the precedent that has been set by the Government.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I depart this chamber and, with a bit of luck, these shores, I would like to say a few words. What the Opposition is seeking is a massive increase in the extent and cost of Telecom Australia's community service obligations. I was reasonably polite about the impact of the amendments and how the issues that they raise might be otherwise addressed. But at the end of the day this is what it really comes down to: the proposed amendments are totally at odds with the rest of the Opposition's approach to this in terms of effective commercial operation, and they are totally at odds with Senator Alston's views on that substance. There is a degree of terrible political cynicism about these amendments in terms of the way in which they have been moved. Whilst I do not want to be other than gentlemanly in my normal appreciation of Senator Alston's motives in raising issues about telecommunications, where I know he has a deep, intense and abiding passion to do the right thing for reasons of high principle, I think he was nodding just a little when it came to moving these amendments. The issues he is concerned about are effectively being addressed in practice. To put in this sort of proposal would be to cut across any effective capacity for the sort of commercial operation that we are talking about, for the price of winning just a few passing super- ficial plaudits. We accordingly reject the amendments.

—I notice that the Minister has said that the bottom line in his rejection of these amendments is the cost. These amendments, if implemented, would reduce the cost. He has just heard what happens when people ring these departments from the bush. The departments say that they will ring the people back. That causes a delay, doubles the amount of work and increases the cost. If the departments had a 008 number people would ring in and the cost would be less than it is now. I implore the Minister to have some commonsense and compassion and to give some equity to the people in remoter areas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before Senator Evans departs, I thought he was about to give me a figure, but he seemed to be distracted by the need to make a few semi-abusive comments. I ask him at least to throw the dead cat into the ring, if it exists.
—We do not have a figure.
—The Minister does not have it. I see. So he is just prepared to say in general terms-
—We are prepared to make an assumption that it is large.

—His usual hyperbolic approach. I wish to respond to some of the comments made by the Australian Democrats, because I regard them as breathtaking in their cynicism. The Democrats have said that, because the costs of technology in delivering some of these services are falling, that then becomes a reason why we should not hasten the process, no matter how worthwhile it might be to do so, no matter how deserving people's needs might be, no matter how much it makes obvious commonsense and no matter that the Government is already in the process of implementing them. In other words, on this one occasion the Democrats are arguing that technology will take care of the problem and that over time costs will reduce to the point where these services are affordable. This is completely at odds with their social approach to all these other issues, where they are constantly pleading for special benefits and for concessions to be made to those who might have economic difficulty in otherwise affording these services, yet they are prepared to put forward these half-baked proposals irrespective of cost. That they then have the cheek to suggest to us that somehow we should address the question of cost when the Government itself has indicated that Telecom is in the process of introducing these sorts of arrangements I find hypocritical in the extreme. All we are seeking is for the Parliament to declare its intention. That would then provide Telecom with a bolster that would enable it to deliver on the program that Senator Evans has said is already in place.

SPEECH.PARA: The last thing that I need to say is this: I cannot believe the confused thinking that accompanies the Democrats' approach to this and other amendments. The suggestion that somehow we can introduce an amendment which, on its face, standing alone, is desirable, but that the possibility of some hidden agenda that involves privatisation becomes a reason for rejecting that proposal on the merits, strikes me as absolutely extraordinary.

TALK.START.PARA: —At what price?

—I do not know what the price is. Obviously the Democrats cannot even understand the name of the game, let alone what it costs. If we have any comprehension of what is involved in amending legislation, surely we know that, if we move to strengthen an Act in a particular place, that remains the change to the legislation, irrespective of what changes might be made elsewhere or what another government might do to that Act at another time. For the time being, the amendment that we propose-like the one we proposed last night-would strengthen the current Act. That seems to be what the Democrats say in all their rhetoric, but when it comes to the crunch it is the very sort of thing they reject on the unholy ground that somehow we have a hidden agenda.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to have to say it again and again: we are concerned about delivering efficient and effective telecommunications services at the lowest possible cost. I do not regard privatisation as a high priority area in achieving that aim. I do regard competition-and therefore deregulation-as very important in driving down the cost of those services and at the same time ensuring that we can deliver to those in need by cross-subsidy arrangements. Certainly, that can be done not only, as the Democrats suggest, by off-budget subvention but just as easily by a levy on all telecommunications users. To suggest that, somehow, the fact that at some time people talk about the privatisation of Telecom is an excuse for rejecting something that one would otherwise wholeheartedly support on the merits strikes me as extraordinary and as forfeiting any respect in this place on these issues. We will therefore be dividing on this amendment to expose the hypocrisy of the Democrats' approach.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I referred earlier to the woolly thinking of the Australian Democrats on this issue, and I would like to reinforce what I said. This amendment highlights the policy commitment that telephone users-and I stress the word `users'-in rural and remote areas should be able to make telephone calls free of charge to the nearest regional office of government departments or agencies. As Senator Sheil has pointed out on a number of occasions, the use of 008 numbers is envisaged. My understanding of the increased facility and technology that is available is that the use of a 008 number might not be free of charge but is in effect subject to a local call charge to the agency or the department that the user may be seeking to call: the consumer or the user in the remote area makes a call at a local charge; the additional costs are then picked up by the department or the person who is registered as the holder of that 008 number.

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, there would be no loss of revenue to Telecom Australia in the operation of the intent of this amendment and it would greatly assist people in rural and remote areas of Australia. For example, let me point out that in the Northern Territory there are dozens of Aboriginal communities where it is necessary for Aboriginal citizens to make extensive use of Telecom services in dealing with government departments and agencies such as the Department of Social Security, the Department of Employment, Education and Training and the Department of Community Services and Health. I can assure honourable senators that those Aboriginal constituents in the Northern Territory do not like standing at public telephone boxes with dozens of coins listening to the recorded music while they wait for departments to engage in their discussions or, alternatively, as Senator Sheil pointed out, in the expectation that there will be departmental easy returns. Often the people dealing with those departments have to go through a number of referral agencies within the department before they can get the appropriate services that they require.

I believe the intent of this amendment to strike at the very provision of policy, to provide for telephone users in these remote areas to be able to make those calls, is the important issue that is at stake. I am surprised that we do not enjoy the support of the Democrats on this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Tambling has drawn attention to a particular problem with this amendment. I suggested earlier that one procedure which is currently quite often used is a reverse charge procedure-a free of charge call-which would meet this amendment. As Senator Tambling has pointed out, the envisaging of a 008 number does not meet this amendment, a 008 call being charged at the rate of a local call.
—It does. The cost is borne by the department.

—The cost other than the local call cost, obviously. I think we have a problem with the terms of the amendment in any case because, clearly, it is currently open to people to use the reverse charge system. It is extraordinarily rare for me to get a call in my office from a needy constituent other than a reverse charge call. I am not quite sure why that does not happen in Senator Tambling's case, to the extent that he has now received some advice from the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) about the use of 008 calls.

SPEECH.PARA: When I was talking about cost earlier, I was not talking about loss of revenue to Telecom Australia; I was talking about the very point that Senator Tambling made, which concerned the question of whether the Opposition in putting this amendment to us had done any costing with regard to those government departments which it is talking about. I do not have any particular argument about that. As I have said all along, a reverse charge call, which is genuinely free of charge, is available to constituents, and a reverse charge call--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not free of charge at all; it is paid for by the department.

SPEECH.PARA: (13) Pages 11 and 12, clause 36, line 33 (page 11) to line 1 (page 12), leave out the clause, insert the following clause:
Declaration of policy-supply and reserved services
``36. It is the intention of the Parliament that the carriers should have the exclusive right to supply public switched telephone services.

This amendment seeks to omit all those reserved services that are specified in the clause other than that in paragraph (a), which is public switched telephone services. What this is about is quite simple. Accepting the Government's present approach and accepting the pseudo-justification that is constantly put forward for the maintenance of the monopoly, it makes sense in those terms to allow Telecom Australia to remain a monopoly provider of the basic telephone service. But it is another thing altogether then to attempt to justify the monopoly on the basis of non-core services, some of which are entirely commercial, for which it is not appropriate at all that Telecom should have the exclusive right to provide. We would not have any objection to Telecom being a competitor for those services, but it is my understanding that public switched data services and text and video services are not big revenue earners for Telecom. They could not conceivably affect Telecom's economic capacity to deliver its community service obligations or to provide revenue to support the burden of the cross-subsidies.

Integrated services digital networks (ISDN) is a classic area of gold plating in which Telecom is desperately keen to sink many millions of dollars. The numbers I have seen recently suggest that it wants to spend something like $200m over the next few years on ISDN and perhaps up to $1,000m over the next decade. Again, that is a very big commercial decision. That is going to cost Telecom money. It has nothing to do at this stage of the game with providing any excess revenue to support the monopoly and, therefore, it is not a service that needs to be protected by way of reserved services. Leased circuit services, again, go to the heart of the monopoly in one sense, but there is no doubt that ultimately it is a very inefficient way of providing for the operation of leased circuit services to insist that they be provided only by a monopolist. Therefore, we take the view that they provide an opportunity to introduce competition into that area.

As far as public mobile telephone services are concerned, that is little more than a scandal. It is an area in which the task force itself could see no justification until it was bludgeoned over the head by the Government and the Caucus Liaison Committee. It eventually came up with a compromise that would allow Telecom to retain the monopoly rights for the time being, subject to a review by Austel, which, hopefully, will take place in the not too distant future. But it is indefensible. If one looks at international experience, one sees that in almost every Western country there are at least two providers of the cellular mobile telephone service. Public mobile telephone services, being a generic term beyond that, are in dramatic demand, which Telecom is not currently able to meet. Its wants to spend a lot of money to try to keep this area of activity to itself and there are a number of competitors very anxious to get into the game. The result of their entry would be that the cost of these services would be driven down dramatically. The costs in the United States I think are approximately 40 per cent cheaper than they are in Australia at the present time. There is no reason to doubt that those kinds of efficiencies could be achieved here in due course, once other competitors are allowed into the market. Our amendment, therefore, would involve stripping the monopoly areas back to the basic network, which is what Telecom is supposed to be all about. If it wants to get into all of those other areas, let it do so on a competitive basis. Let us talk about ways and means of maintaining the cross-subsidy arrangement but it does not need to be done under the transparent guise of a monopoly over a whole range of areas which do not presently generate much revenue at all for Telecom.

This amendment seeks to delete the whole of part 4-in other words, clauses 70 to 104-which deals with value added services and private network services. The Opposition has in mind that there should be another less intrusive and less interventionist regulatory regime. Rather than requiring any person interested in having a new service licence to apply for a variation of a class licence, Austel would simply monitor the situation and, where necessary, would be empowered to call on new applicants to show cause why they should not be prohibited from providing new services and facilities. Obviously, such people would need to be given an opportunity to be heard and to argue why their service should not be declared a reserved service. Ultimately, such persons should have automatic rights of appeal, by way of requiring Austel to reconsider the matter, and ultimately to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Austel would be empowered to order disconnections or to refuse to allow new connections. It would be able to order a reconnection if for any reason the service had already been disconnected or if it had ordered a disconnection, pending the hearing of a matter and was then not satisfied that any offence had been committed. We do not believe that any irreparable harm would flow from such an approach. It is technically feasible to connect and disconnect both value added services and private network services.

We believe there is a fundamental difference of approach between what we propose and what the Government has in mind. As the current regime is worded, it would require Austel to become involved in the minutaie of licences where there is no danger of any interference with the reserve services and-as it is expressed in the United States-no harm to the network. In most instances such new services would be uncontroversial and there would be no potential infringements against the basic network. The Government's regime is a classic bureaucratic solution which would require every new applicant to obtain a variation to a class licence and be put through a whole range of procedures which would no doubt require the usual mountain of paperwork and perhaps even the retention of expensive lawyers in order to ensure that Austel was ultimately satisfied. We regard that as an inefficient and costly approach and one that is not necessary. The hands-off approach, which would be just as effective, would give Austel the overriding power to monitor the situation and to intervene only where necessary.

At the end of the day we do not see that there are many fly-by-night operators likely to be attracted to the telecommunications industry. Those who are in the game are there to make a profit, to operate in the medium to long term and to turn a dollar over a period. It is very difficult to imagine that anyone would deliberately set out to sabotage the network and his own reputation or to try to flout both the spirit and the letter of the boundary provisions for basic network services. Of course, it would always be possible for someone so minded to commit an act of sabotage, whether or not a licence had been or was about to be granted. The mere requirement for legal formalities does not provide any additional protection. We see this clause as a quite unnecessary layer of regulation.

Our amended clause 81 would require the carriers to provide equal access and a level of network functionality to all aspects of the basic network. It would require that preferential information and access not be given to the carriers' own competitive enterprise but that there be fairness between competitors. Our proposed new clause 82 (3) is very important. The carriers would be required to publish a statement of any bulk discounts, rules, or variations, which must be cost based and equally available to all. We believe that there is some blurring in the Government's provisions that does not satisfy the demands of the industry or consumers for transparency in this area, and we think it is necessary that those specific obligations should be placed on the carriers. It is important, if there are problems, that the carriers apprehend them. The carriers would be empowered to approach the Federal Court and obtain injunctions to restrain any abuse of the system.

In particular, we consider that the current provisions in relation to transparency are inadequate and that in addition the three areas in which the carriers-Telecom in particular-would be required to maintain accounts and records should be supplemented by additional requirements which would enable the ready identification of the cost of Telecom meeting its community service obligations and the cost of and prices charged for reserved services used in the carrier's competitive activities. Unless those provisions are explicitly contained, we believe there is scope for fudging the issue. We do not believe that it will then be possible to ascertain, with any degree of accuracy, the nature and extent and, most importantly, the cost burden of Telecom's CSOs. We do not believe it will be possible to ensure that there is no economic cross-subsidisation between Telecom's reserved and competitive services.

We regard the amendments as very necessary and important. They would provide all the necessary protections that we believe are essential, but at the same time they would do away with much of the unnecessary bureaucracy and paperwork that is clearly involved in the Government's approach. No doubt it is inspired by the Department, which always likes to keep control of these matters, and no doubt Telecom itself has a vested interest in ensuring that it has advance notice. The real vice, of course, is that, having created this bureaucratic solution, it is necessary to impose licence fees on all applications for variation in order to fund the very regime that is unnecessary in the first place. We regard this approach as imposing unnecessary and costly burdens which can be done away with without any detriment to the consumers and replaced by adequate safeguards which will be just as effective.

It said that it should be the responsibility of Austel to deal with policy matters and that it should be the responsibility of the Ombudsman to deal with consumer complaints. That strikes me as a sensible dichotomy. I do not see why Austel, given the whole range of burdens that will be imposed upon it, should have to take up what can quite often be very substantial quantities of complaints even though quite often they are relatively minor in themselves. We know that already the Ombudsman's time is taken up with many hundreds of complaints about Telecom related matters. I think the figure in the annual report was something in excess of 20 per cent of the total complaints relate to telecommunications issues. These include issues of service, issues of connection, issues of fees and issues of non-receipt of itemised accounts and billing. These are all matters that should not pre-occupy an independent regulator. They are matters that essentially should be dealt with by someone who has a special charter to deal with consumer complaints.

We therefore find it odd, in the extreme, that Austel is not given specific directions to set those priorities out clearly but may simply so decide to transfer certain complaints to the Ombudsman. That lack of clarity is regrettable. We therefore add a subclause that provides:

In other words, that matter could not be referred to the Ombudsman where such issues arise. But clearly where consumer complaints arise Austel would still retain the power-and ought to in ordinary circumstances-to transfer those complaints to the Ombudsman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak very briefly to this amendment which basically deals with consumer complaints and in rising to support the Australian Democrats' stance which continues the provision for flexibilities as far as consumer complaints are concerned, I would just like to backtrack very briefly on something that Senator Alston said previously. Senator Alston actually made a complaint about Telecom. He said that his telephone was not working and that he sought to get it fixed over the weekend, but Telecom was not prepared to do that because it thought he was an ordinary person.

SPEECH.PARA: I would just like to relate something that happened to me a few years ago when I certainly was a very ordinary person, just as I regard myself as being now, incidentally. I also had a phone which was out of order. I felt that it should be fixed even though it was the weekend because I happened to have an elderly relative with me who was not in the best of health. I put this to Telecom and the phone was fixed so that it was working over the weekend. I wondered whether Telecom in Western Australia is different from Telecom in Victoria which seems to be the State in which Senator Alston has had his experience. I contacted Telecom in Western Australia this afternoon to see exactly what its policy was with telephone repairs over weekends. It regards a weekend service primarily as an emergency service, but it does have a great deal of flexibility. Saturday is regarded as emergency call day, but can be regarded as a regular call day for people who cannot be home on other days. In fact, last Saturday in the north Perth region, which is the region within which I live, Telecom dealt with 176 faults. That would cover about one-third of the metropolitan area. It had 15 men working out of a possible 60. On the previous Saturday it actually fixed 360 telephones. Sunday is regarded as a life and limb service day. The servicemen try not to come out on Sundays whenever possible; however, Telecom is considering extending that service too.

If the amendments which Senator Alston is putting forward had got through-they would cause more deregulation and would put us well on the way to privatisation-he seems to feel that the service would be improved. I do not know whether he has ever tried to get a washing machine, water heater or fridge fixed over the weekend by private people. From my experience and the experience of other people, I can tell him that that is extremely difficult to do over the weekend in the private sector.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether that is meant to be an apologia for Telecom that requires a response from me, but can I simply say by way of response--
—What is wrong with facts?

—If the honourable senator wants to know the facts, they are that Telecom has an explicit policy-I will provide details of this to the Senate at a later time-that makes it very clear that it does not regard itself as under an obligation to provide services at the weekend except in cases of emergency. It does that because it takes a lowest common denominator approach when it does not need to take that approach. Perhaps the real reason is that it is reluctant to accede to exorbitant union demands which would probably involve the payment of triple time at weekends. But for whatever reason, it takes the view that it should only provide reasonable services at reasonable prices. It interprets that to mean that there should be no surcharge able to be paid by those people who might actually be prepared to pay at weekends.

SPEECH.PARA: One can quibble about whether there is a desperate need to have a phone connected over the weekend other than in times of emergency, but if there are people around who are prepared to pay for it, it seems to me that that should be a choice available to consumers. It is not a matter for Telecom with its billion dollar profit figure to somehow decide that it should take an across-the-board approach that restricts those options.

Whatever Senator Jenkins might have discovered about the situation in Western Australia, it cuts no ice with me at all in terms of my experience in Victoria and the subsequent follow-up that we have gleaned from discussions with Telecom's corporate relations department. I will table the policy as it has been explained to me. All that the Democrats are doing, once again, is feeling the need to provide a Pavlovian response to any criticism that might be made of Telecom because they have a misguided notion that if anyone is able to sustain a valid criticism of a service, somehow it might jeopardise the retention of that service in the hands of the public sector. Yet again, Senator Jenkins trotted out this pathetic line about some threat that might derive from privatisation. That is the ultimate obsession of those Democrats who are interested in public sector issues. They are terrified of the notion of privatisation. They have no concept of what might be involved in privatisation other than that it is an unholy transfer of power from one sector-good-to another sector-bad.

What we are about, as I have said constantly in this place and elsewhere, is producing results for consumers that will deliver more efficient outcomes at lower prices. That is not necessarily achieved by privatisation. We saw what happened in the United Kingdom when a monopoly was replaced with a duopoly. In my view, that is not necessarily a satisfactory outcome. What is needed is a competitive environment in which there are very real structural incentives for prices and service to be provided much more efficiently and at a lower charge than at present. Unless and until the Democrats come to grips with that, the sort of response that we have had-the response of throwing one's hands up in the air when anyone criticises the public sector on the basis that somehow it is a Trojan horse for privatisation-will be treated with the contempt that it deserves.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Alston raises a very important point which is covered by clause 68 of the Bill, under which Austel has sufficient power to issue directions to a carrier following an investigation. This is a point which the Government has already taken into account.

—I wish to pursue that matter. I have not had a chance to look at it in detail. Clause 68 relates to reserved services. The matters that Austel is empowered to investigate under clause 148 do not seem to me to be reserved services. Telecommunications services, customer equipment and cabling work are quite explicitly areas where competition is allowed and, therefore, they are non-reserved services.

—Investigations in respect of reserved services are obviously well and truly covered by this particular clause. In the case of other services, I am advised that the Trade Practices Act has direct impact on this.

—The real answer to the question is that the Trade Practices Act covers the point. Why, therefore, is there a need at all for Austel to investigate those matters if it is not at the very least required to report to the Trade Practices Commission? Alternatively, why does the Trade Practices Commission not have the power to conduct the investigation in the first instance?

—The response-I ask Senator Alston to take this into account-is twofold. Austel does have the power to refer matters to the Trade Practices Commission (TPC). —Austel can investigate only those matters in respect of which it has already received complaints. In those situations, it would seem to me that clause 153 does not either entitle it or compel it to refer matters to the Trade Practices Commission.

—The point Senator Alston is concerned about is one of reserved services. The point he has just raised in discussion is one that would be consequently covered by clause 68. We are talking about an area of activity which is a reserved service.
—We are going around in circles. I thought that the Minister had accepted that those three subject matters in clause 148 were not in respect of reserved services.
—If the honourable senator looks at clauses 148 (a) and 148 (b), he will be looking at reserved services.
—No. Customer equipment is classicly an example of a competitive area.
—We are talking about interconnection as well-connection and interconnection-which is also a reserved service in terms of connection to the network.
—Does this cover cabling work?
